translated: He who worships him thus, attains the whole life in this world. Death does not come to him before his time.🔽Gargya said, 'The person who is in the self, on him indeed do I meditate as Brahman.'

original: hovācājātaśatrurmā maitasmintsaṃvadiṣṭhā ātmanvīti vā ahametamupāsa iti sa ya🔽etamevamupāsta ātmanvī ha bhavatyātmanvinī hāsya prajā bhavati sa ha tūṣṇīmāsa
analyzed: ha uvāca ajātaśatruḥ mā mā etasmin saṃvadiṣṭhāḥ ātmanvī iti vai aham etam upāse iti sa yaḥ  etam evam upāste ātmanvī ha bhavati ātmanvinī ha asya prajā bhavati sa ha tūṣṇīm āsa
translated: Ajatasatru said, 'Do not dispute with me about this. I worship him as the embodied one.'

original: gārgyaḥ / / /🔽sa hovācājātaśatruḥ naitāvatā viditam bhavatīti sa hovāca
analyzed: gārgyaḥ  sa ha uvāca ajātaśatruḥ na etāvatā viditam bhavati iti sa ha uvāca
translated: He who worships him thus becomes embodied himself, and his offspring becomes embodied. Gargya became silent.

original: gārgya upa tvāyānīti / / /🔽sa hovācājātaśatruḥ pratilomaṃ vai tadyadbrāhmaṇaḥ kṣatriyamupeyādbrahma me🔽vakṣyatīti vyeva tvā jñapayiṣyāmīti tam pāṇāvādāyottasthau tau ha puruṣaṃ
analyzed: gārgyaḥ upa tvā ayāni iti  sa ha uvāca ajātaśatruḥ pratilomam vai tat yat brāhmaṇaḥ kṣatriyam upeyāt brahma me  vakṣyati iti vi eva tvā jñapayiṣyāmi iti tam pāṇau ādāya uttasthau tau ha puruṣam
translated: Ajatasatru said, 'By this much it is not known.' Gargya said, 'I will come to you.'

original: suptamājagmatustametairnāmabhirāmantrayāṃ cakre bṛhanpāṇḍaravāsaḥ soma
analyzed: suptam ājagmatuḥ tam etaiḥ nāmabhiḥ āmantrayām cakre bṛhan pāṇḍara vāsaḥ soma
translated: Ajatasatru said, 'It would be contrary that a Brahmana should approach a Kshatriya, thinking He will tell me about Brahman. I will make you understand.' He stood up, taking him by the hand. They came to a sleeping man. He addressed him with these names: 'The great one, the white-robed one, the Soma-drinker,

original: rājanniti sa nottasthau tam pāṇināpeṣam bodhayāṃ cakāra sa hottasthau / / /
analyzed: rājan iti sa na uttasthau tam pāṇinā apeṣam bodhayām cakāra sa ha uttasthau
translated: The king, he said, he did not rise up; he rubbed him with his hand and awakened him; he rose up.

original: sa hovācājātaśatruḥ yatraiṣa etatsupto'bhūdya eṣa vijñānamayaḥ puruṣaḥ kvaiṣa
analyzed: sa ha uvāca ajātaśatruḥ yatra eṣa etat suptaḥ abhūt yaḥ eṣa vijñāna mayaḥ puruṣaḥ kva eṣa
translated: He said, Ajatasatru, where was this person who consists of knowledge when he was asleep?

original: tadābhūtkuta etadāgāditi tadu ha na mene gārgyaḥ / / /🔽sa hovācājātaśatruḥ yatraiṣa etatsupto'bhūdya eṣa vijñānamayaḥ puruṣastadeṣām
analyzed: tat abhūt kutas etat āgāt iti tat u ha na mene gārgyaḥ  sa ha uvāca ajātaśatruḥ yatra eṣaḥ etat suptaḥ abhūt yaḥ eṣa vijñāna mayaḥ puruṣaḥ tat eṣām
translated: Where did he come from? But Gargya did not accept it.🔽He said, Ajatasatru, where this person who consists of knowledge was when he was asleep, then he took away the knowledge of these

original: prāṇānāṃ vijñānena vijñānamādāya ya eṣo'ntarhṛdaya ākāśastasmiñceti / / /
analyzed: prāṇānām vijñānena vijñānam ādāya yaḥ eṣaḥ antar hṛdaye ākāśaḥ tasmin ca iti
translated: prāṇas with his knowledge and went into that space within the heart.

original: tāni yadā gṛhṇāti atha haitatpuruṣaḥ svapiti nāma tadgṛhīta eva prāṇo bhavati gṛhītā
analyzed: tāni yadā gṛhṇāti atha ha etat puruṣaḥ svapiti nāma tad gṛhītaḥ eva prāṇaḥ bhavati gṛhītā
translated: When he seizes them, then this person is said to be sleeping. Then the prāṇa is indeed seized,

original: vāggṛhītaṃ cakṣurgṛhītaṃ śrotraṃ gṛhītam manaḥ / / /🔽sa yatraitatsvapnyayā carati te hāsya lokāstaduteva mahārājo bhavatyuteva
analyzed: vāc gṛhītam cakṣuḥ gṛhītam śrotram gṛhītam manaḥ  sa yatra etat svapnyayā carati te ha asya lokāḥ tat uta iva mahā rājaḥ bhavati uta iva
translated: speech is seized, the eye is seized, the ear is seized, the mind is seized.

original: mahābrāhmaṇa utevoccāvacaṃ nigacati / / /
analyzed: mahābrāhmaṇaḥ uta iva uccāvacam nigacati
translated: When he moves about in a dream, those are his worlds. Then he becomes as it were a great king, as it were a great brāhmaṇa, as it were he goes up and down.

original: sa yathā mahārājo jānapadāngṛhītvā sve janapade yathākāmam
analyzed: sa yathā mahā rājaḥ jānapadān gṛhītvā sve janapade yathākāmam
translated: As a great king, having seized the people of his realm, goes about in his own realm as he wishes,🔽so this person, having seized the prāṇas, goes about in these worlds as he wishes.

original: parivartetaivamevaiṣa etatprāṇāngṛhītvā sve śarīre yathākāmam parivartate / / /🔽atha yadā suṣupto bhavati yadā na kasya cana veda hitā nāma nāḍyo dvāsaptatiḥ
analyzed: parivarteta evam eva eṣa etat prāṇān gṛhītvā sve śarīre yathākāmam parivartate  atha yadā suṣuptaḥ bhavati yadā na kasya cana veda hitāḥ nāma nāḍyaḥ dvāsaptatiḥ
translated: In the same way, having taken up the vital airs, he moves about in his own body as he likes.🔽Now when he is in deep sleep, when he knows nothing at all, there are arteries called the 'vital airs' (hita), seventy-two thousand,

original: sahasrāṇi hṛdayātpurītatamabhipratiṣṭhante tābhiḥ pratyavasṛpya purītati śete / / /
analyzed: sahasrāṇi hṛdayāt purītatam abhipratiṣṭhante tābhiḥ pratyavasṛpya purītati śete
translated: which go from the heart to the navel. Having gone out by them, he lies in the navel.

original: sa yathā kumāro vā mahābrāhmaṇo vā 'tighnīmānandasya gatvā śayītaivamevaiṣa
analyzed: sa yathā kumāraḥ vā mahābrāhmaṇaḥ vā tighnīm ānandasya gatvā śayīta evam eva eṣa
translated: Just as a boy or a great Brahmin, having gone to a very comfortable place, would lie down, so does he

original: etacete / / /
analyzed: eta ca ite
translated: in this way.

original: sa yathorṇavābhistantunoccaret yathāgneḥ kṣudrā viṣphuliṅgā
analyzed: sa yathā ūrṇavābhiḥ tantunā uccaret yathā agneḥ kṣudrāḥ viṣphuliṅgā
translated: Just as threads come out of wool, as small sparks come out of fire,

original: vyuccarantyevamevāsmādātmanaḥ sarve prāṇāḥ sarve lokāḥ sarve devāḥ sarvāṇi
analyzed: vyuccaranti evam eva asmāt ātmanaḥ sarve prāṇāḥ sarve lokāḥ sarve devāḥ sarvāṇi
translated: in the same way all the vital airs, all the worlds, all the gods, all the

original: bhūtāni
analyzed: bhūtāni
translated: beings,

original: sarva eta ātmāno vyuccaranti tasyopaniṣatsatyasya satyamiti prāṇā vai satyaṃ
analyzed: sarve ete ātmānaḥ vyuccaranti tasya upaniṣad satyasya satyam iti prāṇāḥ vai satyam
translated: all these souls come out of this Self. Its Upaniṣad is 'The truth of truth.' The vital airs are the truth.

original: teṣāmeṣa satyam / / /
analyzed: teṣām eṣa satyam
translated: This is their truth.

original: yo ha vai śiśuṃ sādhanaṃ sapratyādhānaṃ sasthūṇaṃ sadāmaṃ veda sapta ha dviṣato
analyzed: yaḥ ha vai śiśum sa ādhanam sa pratyādhānam sa sthūṇam sa dāmam veda sapta ha dviṣataḥ
translated: One who knows the child, the support, the counter-support, the pillar, and the house, subdues seven hateful🔽brothers.

original: bhrātṛvyānavaruṇaddhi / / /
analyzed: bhrātṛvyān avaruṇaddhi
translated: He seizes the younger brother by the arms,

original: ayaṃ vāva śiśuryo'yam madhyamaḥ prāṇaḥ tasyedamevādhānamidam pratyādhānam
analyzed: ayam vāva śiśuḥ yaḥ ayam madhyamaḥ prāṇaḥ tasya idam eva ādhānam idam pratyādhānam
translated: This child, indeed, is the middle vital air; its foundation is this (earth), its support is yonder (sky).

original: prāṇa sthūṇānnaṃ dāma tametāḥ saptākṣitaya upatiṣṭhante / / /
analyzed: prāṇa sthūṇā annam dāma tam etāḥ sapta akṣitayaḥ upatiṣṭhante
translated: The vital air is the pillar, food is the rope; seven eyes attend on it.🔽Rudra is connected with it by those red streaks in the eye,

original: tadyā imā akṣaṃlohinyo rājayaḥ tābhirenaṃ rudro'nvāyatto'tha yā akṣannāpastābhiḥ
analyzed: tat yāḥ imāḥ akṣaṃlohinyaḥ rājayaḥ tābhiḥ enam rudraḥ anvāyattaḥ utha yāḥ akṣan āpaḥ tābhiḥ
translated: Parjanya by those watery ones in the eye,

original: parjanyo yā kanīnakā tayādityo yacuklaṃ tenāgniryatkṛṣṇaṃ tenendro'dharayainaṃ
analyzed: parjanyaḥ yā kanīnakā tayā ādityaḥ yat kṛṣṇam tena indraḥ dharaya enam
translated: the sun by the pupil, Agni by the white (part of the eye), Indra by the black.

original: vartanyā pṛthivyanvāyattā dyauruttarayā nāsyānnaṃ kṣīyate ya evaṃ veda / / /
analyzed: vartanyā pṛthivī anvāyattā dyauḥ uttarayā na asya annam kṣīyate yaḥ evam veda
translated: The earth is connected with it by the lower eyelid, the sky by the upper one; the food of him who knows this does not fail.

original: tadeṣa śloko bhavati arvāgbilaścamasa ūrdhvabudhnastasminyaśo nihitaṃ
analyzed: tat eṣa ślokaḥ bhavati arvāc bilaḥ camasaḥ ūrdhva budhnaḥ tasmin yaśaḥ nihitam
translated: Of it this verse is to be recited: 'The cup with the mouth turned downward and the bottom turned upward, in which is placed the glory of all forms;

original: viśvarūpam tasyāsata ṛṣayaḥ sapta tīre vāgaṣṭamī brahmaṇā saṃvidāneti / / /🔽arvāgbilaścamasa ūrdhvabudhna iti idaṃ tacira eṣa hyarvāgbilaścamasa
analyzed: viśva rūpam tasya āsata ṛṣayaḥ sapta tīre vāc aṣṭamī brahmaṇā saṃvidānā iti  arvāc bilaḥ camasaḥ ūrdhva budhnaḥ iti idam taciraḥ eṣa hi arvāc bilaḥ camasa
translated: on it the seven Ṛṣis sit, and speech, the eighth, in agreement with Brahman.'🔽'The cup with the mouth turned downward and the bottom turned upward' - this is the sky, for it has the mouth turned downward and the bottom turned upward.

original: ūrdhvabudhnastasminyaśo nihitaṃ viśvarūpamiti prāṇā vai yaśo nihitaṃ viśvarūpam
analyzed: ūrdhva budhnaḥ tasmin yaśaḥ nihitam viśva rūpam iti prāṇāḥ vai yaśaḥ nihitam viśva rūpam
translated: 'In which is placed the glory of all forms' - the vital airs are the glory of all forms.

original: prāṇānetadāha tasyāsata ṛṣayaḥ sapta tīra iti prāṇā vā ṛṣayaḥ prāṇānetadāha
analyzed: prāṇān etat āha tasya āsata ṛṣayaḥ sapta tīre iti prāṇāḥ vai ṛṣayaḥ prāṇān etat āha
translated: He says the vital airs. Of that, the seven Ṛṣis are the banks. The Ṛṣis are the vital airs. He says the vital airs.

original: vāgaṣṭamī brahmaṇā saṃvidāneti vāgghyaṣṭamī brahmaṇā saṃvitte / / /
analyzed: vāc aṣṭamī brahmaṇā saṃvidānā iti vāc hi aṣṭamī brahmaṇā saṃvitte
translated: Speech is the eighth, in union with Brahman. For speech is the eighth, in union with Brahman.

original: imāveva gotamabharadvājau ayameva gotamo'yam bharadvāja imāveva
analyzed: imau eva gotama bharadvājau ayam eva gotamaḥ uyam bharadvājaḥ imau eva
translated: These two, Gautama and Bharadvāja, this is Gautama, this is Bharadvāja. These two,

original: viśvāmitrajamadagnī ayameva viśvāmitro'yaṃ jamadagnirimāveva🔽vasaṣṭhikaśyapāvayameva vasiṣṭho'yaṃ kaśyapo vāgevātrirvācā🔽hyannamadyate'ttirha vai nāmaitadyadatririti sarvasyāttā bhavati sarvamasyānnam
analyzed: viśvāmitra jamadagnī ayam eva viśvāmitraḥ yam jamadagniḥ imau eva  vasaṣṭhi kaśyapau ayam eva vasiṣṭhaḥ yam kaśyapaḥ vāc eva atriḥ vācā  hi annam adya tettiḥ ha vai nāma etat yat atriḥ iti sarvasya attā bhavati sarvam asya annam
translated: Viśvāmitra and Jamadagni, this is Viśvāmitra, this is Jamadagni. These two,

original: bhavati ya evaṃ veda / / /🔽dve vāva brahmaṇo rūpe mūrtaṃ caivāmūrtaṃ ca martyaṃ cāmṛtaṃ ca sthitaṃ ca yacca
analyzed: bhavati yaḥ evam veda  dve vāva brahmaṇaḥ rūpe mūrtam ca eva amūrtam ca martyam ca amṛtam ca sthitam ca yat ca
translated: Vasiṣṭha and Kaśyapa, this is Vasiṣṭha, this is Kaśyapa. Speech is Atri. For by speech food is eaten. Atri is indeed this name. He becomes the eater of all. All food belongs to him who knows thus.

original: sacca tyaṃ ca / / /🔽tadetanmūrtam yadanyadvāyoścāntarikṣāccaitanmartyametatsthitametatsat / / /
analyzed: sat ca tyam ca  tat etat mūrtam yat anyat vāyoḥ ca antarikṣāt ca etat martyam etat sthitam etat sat
translated: There are indeed two forms of Brahman, the embodied and the unembodied, the mortal and the immortal, the static and the dynamic, the real and the unreal.🔽This is the embodied, what is other than wind and space. This is mortal, this is static, this is real.

original: tasyaitasya mūrtasyaitasya martyasyaitasya sthitasyaitasya sata eṣa raso ya eṣa tapati
analyzed: tasya etasya mūrtasya etasya martyasya etasya sthitasya etasya sataḥ eṣa rasaḥ yaḥ eṣa tapati
translated: Of this embodied, of this mortal, of this static, of this real, this is the essence, what shines.

original: sato hyeṣa rasaḥ / / /
analyzed: sataḥ hi eṣa rasaḥ
translated: For this is the essence of what exists.

original: athāmūrtam vāyuścāntarikṣaṃ caitadamṛtametadyadetattyam / / /🔽tasyaitasyāmūrtasya etasyāmṛtasyaitasya yata etasya tyasyaiṣa raso ya eṣa
analyzed: atha amūrtam vāyuḥ ca antarikṣam ca etat amṛtam etat yat etat tyam  tasya etasya amūrtasya etasya amṛtasya etasya yatas etasya tyasya eṣa rasaḥ yaḥ eṣa
translated: Now, the formless: the wind and the space - this is immortal, this is that which is called tya.

original: etasminmaṇḍale puruṣastyasya hyeṣa rasa ityadhidevatam / / /🔽athādhyātmam idameva mūrtaṃ yadanyatprāṇācca yaścāyamantarātmannākāśa
analyzed: etasmin maṇḍale puruṣaḥ tyasya hi eṣa rasaḥ iti adhidevatam  atha adhyātmam idam eva mūrtam yat anyat prāṇāt ca yaḥ ca ayam antarātman ākāśa
translated: Of that formless, that immortal, that which is that, that which is called tya, this is the essence, which is the person in this sphere. For he is the essence of tya. Thus, in relation to the gods.

original: etanmartyametatsthitametatsat / / /
analyzed: etat martyam etat sthitam etat sat
translated: Now, in relation to the self: this very form is what is other than the vital breath and this space within the self.🔽This is mortal, this is stable, this is real.

original: tasyaitasya mūrtasya etasya martyasyaitasya sthitasyaitasya sata eṣa raso yaccakṣuḥ
analyzed: tasya etasya mūrtasya etasya martyasya etasya sthitasya etasya sataḥ eṣa rasaḥ yat cakṣuḥ
translated: Of that form, that mortal, that stable, that real, this is the essence, which is the eye.

original: sato hyeṣa rasaḥ / / /
analyzed: sataḥ hi eṣa rasaḥ
translated: For this is the essence of what exists.

original: athāmūrtam prāṇaśca yaścāyamantarātmannākāśa etadamṛtametadyadetattyam / / /
analyzed: atha amūrtam prāṇaḥ ca yaḥ ca ayam antarātman ākāśaḥ etat amṛtam etat yat etat tyam
translated: Now, the formless: the vital breath and this space within the self - this is immortal, this is that which is called tya.

original: tasyaitasyāmūrtasya etasyāmṛtasyaitasya yata etasya tyasyaiṣa raso yo'yaṃ
analyzed: tasya etasya amūrtasya etasya amṛtasya etasya yatas etasya tyasya eṣa rasaḥ yaḥ uyam
translated: Of that formless, that immortal, that which is that, that which is called tya, this is the essence, which is the person

original: dakṣiṇe'kṣanpuruṣastyasya hyeṣa rasaḥ / / /
analyzed: dakṣiṇā īkṣan puruṣaḥ tyasya hi eṣa rasaḥ
translated: in the right eye. For he is the essence of tya.

original: tasya haitasya puruṣasya rūpam yathā māhārajanaṃ vāso yathā pāṇḍvāvikaṃ
analyzed: tasya ha etasya puruṣasya rūpam yathā māhārajanam vāsaḥ yathā pāṇḍvāvikam
translated: Now, the form of that person is like a garment of Mahārajana silk, like a garment of fine wool,

original: yathendragopo yathāgnyarciryathā puṇḍarīkaṃ yathā sakṛdvidyuttaṃ sakṛdvidyutteva
analyzed: yathā indragopaḥ yathā agni arciḥ yathā puṇḍarīkam yathā sakṛt vidyut tam sakṛt vidyut tā iva
translated: Like an indragopa, like a flame of fire, like a lotus, like a flash of lightning, like a flash of lightning

original: ha vā asya śrīrbhavati ya evaṃ veda / / /🔽athāta ādeśo neti neti na hyetasmāditi netyanyatparamastyatha nāmadheyaṃ satyasya
analyzed: ha vai asya śrīḥ bhavati yaḥ evam veda  atha atas ādeśaḥ na iti na iti na hi etasmāt iti na iti anyat param asti atha nāmadheyam satyasya
translated: One who knows thus has his glory like this.

original: satyamiti prāṇā vai satyaṃ teṣāmeṣa satyam / / /
analyzed: satyam iti prāṇāḥ vai satyam teṣām eṣa satyam
translated: Now, therefore, the instruction: 'Not so, not so.' There is nothing higher than this, 'not so, not so.' Then there is a name, 'The truth of truth.' The vital breaths are the truth. This is their truth.

original: maitreyīti hovāca yājñavalkyaḥ udyāsyanvā are'hamasmātsthānādasmi hanta te'nayā
analyzed: maitreyi iti ha uvāca yājñavalkyaḥ udyāsyan vai are ham asmāt sthānāt asmi hanta tena yā
translated: He said to Maitreyi, O Yajnavalkya, I am about to depart from this place. Come, let me conclude with you this

original: kātyāyanyāntaṃ karavāṇīti / / /🔽sa hovāca maitreyī yanma iyam bhagoḥ sarvā pṛthivī vittena pūrṇā syātkathaṃ
analyzed: kātyāyanyā antam karavāṇi iti  sa ha uvāca maitreyī yat me iyam sarvā pṛthivī vittena pūrṇā syāt katham
translated: with Katyayani.

original: tenāmṛtā syāmiti neti hovāca yājñavalkyo yathaivopakaraṇavatāṃ jīvitaṃ tathaiva te
analyzed: tena amṛtā syām iti na iti ha uvāca yājñavalkyaḥ yathā eva upakaraṇavatām jīvitam tathā eva te
translated: He said to Maitreyi, If this entire earth filled with wealth were mine, would I be immortal by that? No, said Yajnavalkya, your life would be like that of those who have means,

original: jīvitaṃ syādamṛtatvasya tu nāśāsti vitteneti / / /
analyzed: jīvitam syāt amṛta tvasya tu na āśā asti vittena iti
translated: but there is no attainment of immortality by wealth.

original: sā hovāca maitreyī yenāhaṃ nāmṛtā syāṃ kimahaṃ tena kuryāṃ yadeva bhagavānveda
analyzed: sā ha uvāca maitreyī yena aham na amṛtā syām kim aham tena kuryām yat eva bhagavān veda
translated: She said, Maitreyi, by what would I be immortal? What should I do with that by which I would not be immortal? Whatever the revered one knows,

original: tadeva me brūhīti / / /
analyzed: tat eva me brūhi iti
translated: tell that to me.

original: sa hovāca yājñavalkyaḥ priyā vatāre naḥ satī priyam bhāṣasa ehyāsva vyākhyāsyāmi
analyzed: sa ha uvāca yājñavalkyaḥ priyā vatāre naḥ satī priyam bhāṣase ehyāsva vyākhyāsyāmi
translated: Yajnavalkya said, You speak what is dear to us, O dear one. Come, let us sit down. I will explain.

original: te vyācakṣāṇasya tu me nididhyāsasveti bravītu bhagavāniti / / /
analyzed: te vyācakṣāṇasya tu me nididhyāsasva iti bravītu bhagavān iti
translated: While I am explaining, reflect on it. The revered one said, 'Speak.'

original: sa hovāca yājñavalkyo na vā are patyuḥ kāmāya patiḥ priyo bhavatyātmanastu🔽kāmāya patiḥ priyo bhavati navā are jāyāyai kāmāya jāyā priyā bhavatyātmanastu
analyzed: sa ha uvāca yājñavalkyaḥ na vai are patyuḥ kāmāya patiḥ priyaḥ bhavati ātmanaḥ tu  kāmāya patiḥ priyaḥ bhavati navā are jāyāyai kāmāya jāyā priyā bhavati ātmanaḥ tu
translated: Yajnavalkya said, Verily, O dear one, a husband is not dear for the sake of the wife's desire, but a husband is dear for the sake of one's own self.

original: kāmāya jāyā priyā bhavati na vā are putrāṇāṃ kāmāya putrāḥ priyā
analyzed: kāmāya jāyā priyā bhavati na vai are putrāṇām kāmāya putrāḥ priyā
translated: Verily, O dear one, a wife is not dear for the sake of the wife's desire, but a wife is dear for the sake of one's own self. Verily, O dear one, sons are not dear for the sake of the sons' desire,

original: bhavantyātmanastu kāmāya putrāḥ priyā bhavanti na vā are vittasya kāmāya vittam🔽priyam bhavatyātmanastu kāmāya vittam priyam bhavati na vā are brahmaṇaḥ
analyzed: bhavanti ātmanaḥ tu kāmāya putrāḥ priyāḥ bhavanti na vai are vittasya kāmāya vittam  priyam bhavati ātmanaḥ tu kāmāya vittam priyam bhavati na vai are brahmaṇaḥ
translated: but sons are dear for the sake of one's own self. Verily, O dear one, wealth is not dear for the sake of the desire for wealth,

original: kāmāya brahma priyam bhavatyātmanastu kāmāya brahma priyam bhavati na vā are
analyzed: kāmāya brahma priyam bhavati ātmanaḥ tu kāmāya brahma priyam bhavati na vai are
translated: but wealth is dear for the sake of one's own self. Verily, O dear one, Brahman is not dear for the sake of the desire for Brahman, but Brahman is dear for the sake of one's own self. Verily, O dear one,

original: kṣatrasya kāmāya kṣatram priyam bhavatyātmanastu kāmāya kṣatram priyam
analyzed: kṣatrasya kāmāya kṣatram priyam bhavati ātmanaḥ tu kāmāya kṣatram priyam
translated: the Kshatriya is not dear for the sake of the desire for the Kshatriya, but the Kshatriya is dear for the sake of one's own self.

original: bhavati na vā are lokānāṃ kāmāya lokāḥ priyā bhavantyātmanastu kāmāya lokāḥ priyā
analyzed: bhavati na vai are lokānām kāmāya lokāḥ priyāḥ bhavanti ātmanaḥ tu kāmāya lokāḥ priyāḥ
translated: The worlds are dear, O dear one, either for the sake of the self or for the sake of the worlds.

original: bhavanti na vā are devānāṃ kāmāya devāḥ priyā bhavantyātmanastu kāmāya devāḥ
analyzed: bhavanti na vai are devānām kāmāya devāḥ priyāḥ bhavanti ātmanaḥ tu kāmāya devāḥ
translated: The gods are dear, O dear one, either for the sake of the self or for the sake of the gods.

original: priyā bhavanti na vā are bhūtānāṃ kāmāya bhūtāni priyāṇi bhavantyātmanastu
analyzed: priyāḥ bhavanti na vai are bhūtānām kāmāya bhūtāni priyāṇi bhavanti ātmanaḥ tu
translated: The beings are dear, O dear one, either for the sake of the self or for the sake of the beings.

original: kāmāya
analyzed: kāmāya
translated: For the sake of the self,

original: bhūtāni priyāṇi bhavanti na vā are sarvasya kāmāya sarvam priyam bhavatyātmanastu
analyzed: bhūtāni priyāṇi bhavanti na vai are sarvasya kāmāya sarvam priyam bhavati ātmanaḥ tu
translated: the beings are dear. All is dear, O dear one, either for the sake of the self or for the sake of all. For the sake of the self,

original: kāmāya sarvam priyam bhavatyātmā vā are draṣṭavyaḥ śrotavyo mantavyo
analyzed: kāmāya sarvam priyam bhavati ātmā vai are draṣṭavyaḥ śrotavyaḥ mantavyaḥ
translated: all is dear. The self, O dear one, should be seen, heard, thought,

original: nididhyāsitavyo maitreyyātmano vā are darśanena śravaṇena matyā vijñānenedaṃ
analyzed: nididhyāsitavyaḥ maitreyi ātmanaḥ vai are darśanena śravaṇena matyā vijñānena idam
translated: and contemplated. By the vision, hearing, thought, and knowledge of the self, O dear one,

original: sarvaṃ viditam / / /🔽brahma tam parādāt yo'nyatrātmano brahma veda kṣatraṃ tam
analyzed: sarvam viditam  brahma tam parādāt yaḥ nyatra ātmanaḥ brahma veda kṣatram tam
translated: all this is known.

original: parādādyo'nyatrātmanaḥ kṣatraṃ veda lokāstam parāduryo'nyatrātmano lokānveda
analyzed: parādāt yaḥ nyatra ātmanaḥ kṣatram veda lokāḥ tam parāduḥ yaḥ nyatra ātmanaḥ lokān veda
translated: Brahman has passed beyond him who knows Brahman as other than the self. The Kshatriya has passed beyond him who knows the Kshatriya as other than the self. The worlds have passed beyond him who knows the worlds as other than the self.

original: devāstam parāduryo'nyatrātmano devānveda bhūtāni tam parāduryo'nyatrātmano
analyzed: devāḥ tam parāduḥ yaḥ nyatra ātmanaḥ devān veda bhūtāni tam parāduḥ yaḥ nyatra ātmanaḥ
translated: The gods have passed beyond him who knows the gods as other than the self. The beings have passed beyond him who knows the beings as other than the self.

original: bhūtāni veda sarvaṃ tam parādādyo'nyatrātmanaḥ sarvaṃ vededam brahmedaṃ
analyzed: bhūtāni veda sarvam tam parādāt yaḥ nyatra ātmanaḥ sarvam veda idam brahma idam
translated: He knows all beings. He who knows this Brahman, this Kshatra, these worlds, these gods, these beings, all this which is this Self,

original: kṣatramime lokā ime devā imāni bhūtānīdaṃ sarvaṃ yadayamātmā / / /
analyzed: kṣatram ime lokāḥ ime devāḥ imāni bhūtāni idam sarvam yat ayam ātmā
translated: he, verily, is a knower, a speaker of truth, a Brahman-knower.

original: sa yathā dundubherhanyamānasya na bāhyāñcabdāñcaknuyādgrahaṇāya dundubhestu
analyzed: sa yathā dundubheḥ hanyamānasya na bāhyān cabdān caknuyāt grahaṇāya dundubheḥ tu
translated: Just as one cannot grasp the external sounds of a beaten drum, but

original: grahaṇena dundubhyāghātasya vā śabdo bhavati gṛhītaḥ / / /
analyzed: grahaṇena dundubhi āghātasya vā śabdaḥ bhavati gṛhītaḥ
translated: by grasping the drum or the drum-stroke, the sound is grasped.

original: sa yathā vīṇāyai vādyamānāyai na bāhyāñcabdāñcaknuyādgrahaṇāya vīṇāyai tu
analyzed: sa yathā vīṇāyai vādyamānāyai na bāhyān cabdān caknuyāt grahaṇāya vīṇāyai tu
translated: Just as one cannot grasp the external sounds of a played veena, but by

original: grahaṇena vīṇāvādasya vā śabdo gṛhītaḥ / / /
analyzed: grahaṇena vīṇā vādasya vā śabdaḥ gṛhītaḥ
translated: grasping the veena or the playing of the veena, the sound is grasped.

original: sa yathā śaṅkhasya dhmāyamānasya na bāhyāñcabdāñcaknuyādgrahaṇāya śaṅkhasya
analyzed: sa yathā śaṅkhasya dhmāyamānasya na bāhyān cabdān caknuyāt grahaṇāya śaṅkhasya
translated: Just as one cannot grasp the external sounds of a blown conch, but by

original: tu grahaṇena śaṅkhadhmasya vā śabdo gṛhītaḥ / / /🔽sa yathārdraidhāgnerabhyāhitasya pṛthagdhūmā viniścarantyevaṃ vā are'sya mahato
analyzed: tu grahaṇena śaṅkhadhmasya vā śabdaḥ gṛhītaḥ  sa yathā ārdra edha agneḥ abhyāhitasya pṛthak dhūmāḥ viniścaranti evam vai aresya mahataḥ
translated: grasping the conch or the blowing of the conch, the sound is grasped.

original: bhūtasya niśvasitametadyadṛgvedo yajurvedaḥ sāmavedo'tharvāṅgirasa itihāsaḥ
analyzed: bhūtasya niśvasitam etat yat ṛgvedaḥ yajurvedaḥ sāmavedaḥ utharvāṅgirasaḥ itihāsaḥ
translated: Just as from a wet-fuelled fire that is being stoked, separate smokes issue forth, so, my dear, this Ṛg Veda, Yajur Veda, Sāma Veda, Atharva Veda, Itihāsa,

original: purāṇaṃ vidyā upaniṣadaḥ ślokāḥ sūtrāṇyanuvyākhyānāni vyākhyānānyasyaivaitāni
analyzed: purāṇam vidyāḥ upaniṣadaḥ ślokāḥ sūtrāṇi anuvyākhyānāni vyākhyānāni asya eva etāni
translated: The Puranas, the sciences, the Upanishads, the verses, the aphorisms, the commentaries, and the explanations are all of this very one.

original: sarvāṇi niśvasitāni / / /
analyzed: sarvāṇi niśvasitāni
translated: The Puranas, the sciences, the Upanishads, the verses, the aphorisms, the commentaries, and the explanations - all these are his exhalations.

original: sa yathā sarvāsāmapāṃ samudra ekāyanam evaṃ sarveṣāṃ sparśānāṃ
analyzed: sa yathā sarvāsām apām samudraḥ ekāyanam evam sarveṣām sparśānām
translated: As the ocean is the one destination of all waters, so the skin is the one destination of all touches.

original: tvagekāyanamevaṃ sarveṣāṃ gandhānāṃ nāsike ekāyanamevaṃ sarveṣāṃ rasānāṃ
analyzed: tvac ekāyanam evam sarveṣām gandhānām nāsike ekāyanam evam sarveṣām rasānām
translated: As the nose is the one destination of all smells, so the tongue is the one destination of all tastes.

original: jihvaikāyanamevaṃ sarveṣāṃ rūpāṇāṃ cakṣurekāyanamevaṃ sarveṣāṃ śabdānāṃ
analyzed: jihvā ekāyanam evam sarveṣām rūpāṇām cakṣuḥ ekāyanam evam sarveṣām śabdānām
translated: As the eye is the one destination of all forms, so the ear is the one destination of all sounds.

original: śrotramekāyanamevaṃ sarveṣāṃ saṃkalpānām mana ekāyanamevaṃ sarveṣāṃ🔽vedānāṃ hṛdayamekāyanamevaṃ sarveṣāṃ karmaṇāṃ hastāvekāyanamevaṃ🔽sarveṣāmadhvanāṃ pādāvekāyanamevaṃ sarveṣāmānandānandānāmupastha
analyzed: śrotram ekāyanam evam sarveṣām saṃkalpānām manaḥ ekāyanam evam sarveṣām  vedānām hṛdayam ekāyanam evam sarveṣām karmaṇām hastau ekāyanam evam  sarveṣām adhvanām pādau ekāyanam evam sarveṣām ānanda ānandānām upastha
translated: As the mind is the one destination of all intentions, so the heart is the one destination of all Vedas.🔽As the hands are the one destination of all actions, so the feet are the one destination of all paths.🔽As the genitals are the one destination of all joys and pleasures, so the anus is the one destination of all expulsions.

original: ekāyanamevaṃ sarveṣāṃ visargāṇām pāyurekāyanamevaṃ sarvāsāṃ vidyānāṃ🔽vāgekāyanam / / /
analyzed: eka ayanam evam sarveṣām visargāṇām pāyuḥ eka ayanam evam sarvāsām vidyānām  vāc ekāyanam
translated: As speech is the one destination of all knowledge,

original: sa yathā saindhavakhilyaḥ udake prāsta udakamevānuvilīyeta nāhāsyodgrahaṇāyeva
analyzed: sa yathā saindhava khilyaḥ udake prāstaḥ udakam eva anuvilīyeta na aha asya udgrahaṇāya iva
translated: just as a lump of salt thrown into water would dissolve in the water and there would be no grasping it,

original: syādyatoyatastvādadīta lavaṇamevaivaṃ vā ara idam mahadbhūtamanantamapāraṃ
analyzed: syāt yatas yatas tu ādadīta lavaṇam eva evam vai are idam mahat bhūtam anantam apāram
translated: From whatever source he may take it, even so, O revered one, this is a great element, infinite, boundless.

original: vijñānaghana evaitebhyo bhūtebhyaḥ samutthāya tānyevānuvinaśyati na pretya
analyzed: vijñāna ghanaḥ eva etebhyaḥ bhūtebhyaḥ samutthāya tāni eva anuvinaśyati na pretya
translated: This is only a mass of knowledge, having risen from these elements, it perishes along with them. After death

original: saṃjñāstītyare bravīmīti hovāca yājñavalkyaḥ / / /
analyzed: saṃjñā asti iti are bravīmi iti ha uvāca yājñavalkyaḥ
translated: there is no consciousness, this I tell you, O revered one.'

original: sā hovāca maitreyī atraiva mā bhagavānamūmuhanna pretya saṃjñāstīti / / /
analyzed: sā ha uvāca maitreyī atra eva mā bhagavān amūmuhat na pretya saṃjñā asti iti
translated: Maitreyi said, 'In this very matter, revered sir, do not confuse me, saying that after death there is no consciousness.'

original: sa hovāca yājñavalkyo na vā are ham moham bravīmyalaṃ vā ara idaṃ vijñānāya / / /🔽yatra hi dvaitamiva bhavati taditara itaram paśyati taditara itaraṃ jighrati taditara
analyzed: sa ha uvāca yājñavalkyaḥ na vai are ham moham bravīmi alam vai are idam vijñānāya  yatra hi dvaitam iva bhavati tat itaraḥ itaram paśyati tat itaraḥ itaram jighrati tat itara
translated: Yajnavalkya said, 'I do not, revered lady, say that you are confused. This is enough for the knowledge, revered lady.

original: itaramabhivadati taditara itaraṃ śṛṇoti taditara itaram manute taditara itaraṃ vijānāti / / /🔽yatra tvasya sarvamātmaivābhūt tatkena kam paśyettatkena kaṃ jighrettatkena
analyzed: itaram abhivadati tat itaraḥ itaram śṛṇoti tat itaraḥ itaram manute tat itaraḥ itaram vijānāti  yatra tu asya sarvam ātmā eva abhūt tat kena kam paśyet tat kena kam jighret tat kena
translated: Where there is duality as it were, then one sees the other, then one smells the other, then one speaks to the other, then one hears the other, then one thinks of the other, then one understands the other.

original: kamabhivadettatkena kaṃ śṛṇuyāttatkena kam manvīta tatkena kaṃ
analyzed: kam abhivadet tat kena kam śṛṇuyāt tat kena kam manvīta tat kena kam
translated: But when the Self alone is all this, then by what and whom should one see? By what and whom should one smell? By what and whom should one speak to? By what and whom should one hear? By what and whom should one think? By what and whom should one understand?🔽By what and whom should one know? By what and whom should one desire? By what and whom should one hate? By what and whom should one love? By what and whom should one be angry? By what and whom should one be happy? By what and whom should one grieve? By what and whom should one fear? By what and whom should one be afraid?

original: vijānīyādyenedaṃ sarvaṃ vijānāti taṃ kena vijānīyādvijñātāramare kena vijānīyāditi / / /
analyzed: vijānīyāt yena idam sarvam vijānāti tam kena vijānīyāt vijñātāram are kena vijānīyāt iti
translated: By what could one know him by whom this all is known? By what could one know the knower? By what could one know the knower of the knower?

original: iyam pṛthivī sarveṣām bhūtānām madhvasyai pṛthivyai sarvāṇi bhūtāni madhu🔽yaścāyamasyām pṛthivyāṃ tejomayo'mṛtamayaḥ puruṣo yaścāyamadhyātmaṃ
analyzed: iyam pṛthivī sarveṣām bhūtānām madhu asyai pṛthivyai sarvāṇi bhūtāni madhu  yaḥ ca ayam asyām pṛthivyām tejaḥ mayaḥ umṛta mayaḥ puruṣaḥ yaḥ ca ayam adhyātmam
translated: This earth is the honey of all beings, and all beings are the honey of this earth.

original: śārīrastejomayo'mṛtamayaḥ puruṣo'yameva sa yo'yamātmedamamṛtamidam🔽brahmedaṃ sarvam / / /
analyzed: śārīraḥ tejaḥ mayaḥ umṛta mayaḥ puruṣaḥ yam eva sa yaḥ yam ātmā idam amṛtam idam  brahma idam sarvam
translated: And this person who is in this earth, consisting of light and immortality, and this person who is in the body, consisting of light and immortality, he is that very one who is this self, this is immortality, this is Brahman, this is all.

original: imā āpaḥ sarveṣām bhūtānām madhvāsāmapāṃ sarvāṇi bhūtāni madhu
analyzed: imāḥ āpaḥ sarveṣām bhūtānām madhu āsām apām sarvāṇi bhūtāni madhu
translated: These waters are the honey of all beings, and all beings are the honey of these waters.

original: yaścāyamāsvapsu tejomayo'mṛtamayaḥ puruṣo yaścāyamadhyātmaṃ🔽raitasastejomayo'mṛta / / /
analyzed: yaḥ ca ayam āsu apsu tejaḥ mayaḥ umṛta mayaḥ puruṣaḥ yaḥ ca ayam adhyātmam  raitasaḥ tejaḥ mayaḥ umṛta
translated: And this person who is in these waters, consisting of light and immortality, and this person who is in the semen, consisting of light and immortality, he is that very one who is this self, this is immortality, this is Brahman, this is all.

original: ayamagniḥ sarveṣām bhūtānām madhvasyāgneḥ sarvāṇi bhūtāni madhu🔽yaścāyamasminnagnau tejomayo'mṛtamayaḥ puruṣo yaścāyamadhyātmaṃ
analyzed: ayam agniḥ sarveṣām bhūtānām madhu asya agneḥ sarvāṇi bhūtāni madhu  yaḥ ca ayam asmin agnau tejaḥ mayaḥ umṛta mayaḥ puruṣaḥ yaḥ ca ayam adhyātmam
translated: This fire is the honey of all beings, and all beings are the honey of this fire.

original: vāṅmayastejomayo'mṛta / / /
analyzed: vāc mayaḥ tejaḥ mayaḥ umṛta
translated: And this person who is in this fire, consisting of light and immortality, and this person who is in speech, consisting of light and immortality, he is that very one who is this self, this is immortality, this is Brahman, this is all.

original: ayamākāśaḥ sarveṣām bhūtānām madhvasyākāśasya sarvāṇi bhūtāni madhu
analyzed: ayam ākāśaḥ sarveṣām bhūtānām madhu asya ākāśasya sarvāṇi bhūtāni madhu
translated: This space is the honey of all beings, and all beings are the honey of this space.

original: yaścāyamasminnākāśe tejomayo'mṛtamayaḥ puruṣo yaścāyamadhyātmaṃ
analyzed: yaḥ ca ayam asmin ākāśe tejaḥ mayaḥ umṛta mayaḥ puruṣaḥ yaḥ ca ayam adhyātmam
translated: And this person in the sky, consisting of light and immortality, and this person in the heart,

original: hṛdyākāśastejomayo'mṛta / / /
analyzed: hṛdi ākāśaḥ tejaḥ mayaḥ umṛta
translated: consisting of light and immortality, this is the honey.

original: ayaṃ vāyuḥ sarveṣām bhūtānām madhvasya vāyoḥ sarvāṇi bhūtāni madhu
analyzed: ayam vāyuḥ sarveṣām bhūtānām madhu asya vāyoḥ sarvāṇi bhūtāni madhu
translated: This wind is the honey of all beings, and all beings are the honey of this wind.

original: yaścāyamasminvāyau tejomayo'mṛtamayaḥ puruṣo yaścāyamadhyātmam
analyzed: yaḥ ca ayam asmin vāyau tejaḥ maya umṛta mayaḥ puruṣaḥ yaḥ ca ayam adhyātmam
translated: And this person in the wind, consisting of light and immortality, and this person in the self,

original: prāṇastejomayo'mṛta / / /
analyzed: prāṇaḥ tejaḥ mayaḥ umṛta
translated: consisting of light and immortality, this is the honey.

original: ayamādityaḥ sarveṣām bhūtānām madhvasyādityasya sarvāṇi bhūtāni madhu
analyzed: ayam ādityaḥ sarveṣām bhūtānām madhu asya ādityasya sarvāṇi bhūtāni madhu
translated: This sun is the honey of all beings, and all beings are the honey of this sun.

original: yaścāyamasminnāditye tejomayo'mṛtamayaḥ puruṣo yaścāyamadhyātmaṃ
analyzed: yaḥ ca ayam asmin āditye tejaḥ mayaḥ umṛta mayaḥ puruṣaḥ yaḥ ca ayam adhyātmam
translated: And this person in the sun, consisting of light and immortality, and this person in the self,

original: cakṣuṣastejomayo'mṛta / / /
analyzed: cakṣuṣaḥ tejaḥ mayaḥ umṛta
translated: consisting of light and immortality, this is the honey.

original: ayaṃ candraḥ sarveṣām bhūtānām madhvasya candrasya sarvāṇi bhūtāni madhu
analyzed: ayam candraḥ sarveṣām bhūtānām madhu asya candrasya sarvāṇi bhūtāni madhu
translated: This moon is the honey of all beings, and all beings are the honey of this moon.

original: yaścāyamasmiṃścandre tejomayo'mṛtamayaḥ puruṣo yaścāyamadhyātmam
analyzed: yaḥ ca ayam asmin candre tejaḥ mayaḥ umṛta mayaḥ puruṣaḥ yaḥ ca ayam adhyātmam
translated: And this person in the moon, consisting of light and immortality, and this person in the self,

original: mānasastejomayo'mṛta / / /
analyzed: mānasaḥ tejaḥ mayaḥ umṛta
translated: consisting of light and immortality, this is the honey.

original: imā diśaḥ sarveṣām bhūtānām madhvāsāṃ diśāṃ sarvāṇi bhūtāni madhu
analyzed: imāḥ diśaḥ sarveṣām bhūtānām madhu āsām diśām sarvāṇi bhūtāni madhu
translated: These directions are the honey of all beings, and all beings are the honey of these directions.

original: yaścāyamāsu
analyzed: yaḥ ca ayamāsu
translated: And this person in the directions,

original: dikṣu tejomayo'mṛtamayaḥ puruṣo yaścāyamadhyātmaṃ śrautraḥ
analyzed: dikṣu tejaḥ mayaḥ umṛta mayaḥ puruṣaḥ yaḥ ca ayam adhyātmam śrautraḥ
translated: The person who is full of light and immortality in the directions, and who is heard internally as related to the ear,

original: prātiśrutkastejomayo'mṛta / / /
analyzed: prātiśrutkaḥ tejaḥ mayaḥ umṛta

original: brāhmaṇānāmanūcānatama iti / / /
analyzed: brāhmaṇānām anūcānatamaḥ iti
translated: They came together. Then Janaka of Videha had a desire to know, 'Who among these Brahmins is the most learned in the Veda?'

original: sa ha gavāṃ sahasramavarurodha daśadaśa pādā ekaikasyāḥ śṛṅgayorābaddhā
analyzed: sa ha gavām sahasram avarurodha daśa daśa pādāḥ ekaikasyāḥ śṛṅgayoḥ ābaddhā
translated: He then shut up a thousand cows, ten coins tied to the horns of each one,

original: babhūvustānhovāca brāhmaṇā bhagavanto yo vo brahmiṣṭhaḥ sa etā gā udajatāmiti te
analyzed: babhūvuḥ tān ha uvāca brāhmaṇāḥ bhagavantaḥ yaḥ vaḥ brahmiṣṭhaḥ saḥ etāḥ gāḥ udajatām iti te
translated: and said to the Brahmins, 'O revered ones, let him who is the most learned in the Veda among you take these cows.'

original: ha brāhmaṇā na dadhṛṣuḥ / / /
analyzed: ha brāhmaṇāḥ na dadhṛṣuḥ
translated: But the Brahmins did not dare to take them.

original: atha ha yājñavalkyaḥ svameva brahmacāriṇamuvācaitāḥ saumyodaja iti tā
analyzed: atha ha yājñavalkyaḥ svam eva brahmacāriṇam uvāca etāḥ saumya udaja sāmaśravaḥ iti tāḥ
translated: Then Yajnavalkya said to his own student, 'O Soma, take them.' He took them.

original: hodācakāra te ha brāhmaṇāścukrudhuḥ kathaṃ nu no brahmiṣṭho bruvīteti / / /🔽atha ha janakasya vaide hasya hotāśvalo babhūva sa hainam papraca tvaṃ nu khalu
analyzed: ha udācakāra te ha brāhmaṇāḥ cukrudhuḥ katham nu naḥ brahmiṣṭhaḥ bruvīta iti  atha ha janakasya vaide hasya hotā āśvalaḥ babhūva sa ha enam papraca tvam nu khalu
translated: Then the Brahmins got angry, 'How can our most learned one speak like this?'

original: no yājñavalkya brahmiṣṭho' iti sa hovāca namo vayam brahmiṣṭhāya kurmo
analyzed: na u yājñavalkya brahmiṣṭhā asi iti sa ha uvāca namaḥ vayam brahmiṣṭhāya kurmaḥ
translated: Then Asvala, the Hotri priest of Janaka of Videha, asked him, 'Are you indeed our most learned one, Yajnavalkya?' He said, 'We pay homage to the most learned one.

original: gokāmā eva vayaṃ sma iti taṃ ha tata eva praṣṭuṃ dadhre hotāśvalaḥ / / /
analyzed: go kāmāḥ eva vayam smaḥ iti tam ha tatas eva praṣṭum dadhre hotā āśvalaḥ
translated: We are only desirous of cows.' Then Asvala, the Hotri priest, decided to question him right there.

original: yājñavalkyeti hovāca yadidaṃ sarvam mṛtyunāptaṃ sarvam mṛtyunābhipannaṃ kena
analyzed: yājñavalkya iti ha uvāca yat idam sarvam mṛtyunā āptam sarvam mṛtyunā abhipannam kena
translated: Yajnavalkya, he said, this whole world is encompassed by death, this whole world is overcome by death. By what

original: yajamāno mṛtyorāptimatimucyata iti hotrartvijāgninā vācā vāgvai yajñasya hovtā
analyzed: yajamānaḥ mṛtyoḥ āptim atimucyate iti hotrā ṛtvijā agninā vācā vāc vai yajñasya hovtā
translated: does the sacrificer escape from the reach of death? By the Hotri priest, by speech, by the voice. For the voice is the Hotri of the sacrifice.

original: tadyeyaṃ vākṣo'yamagniḥ sa hotā sā muktiḥ sātimuktiḥ / / /🔽yājñavalkyeti hovāca yadidaṃ sarvamahorātrābhyāmāptaṃ
analyzed: tat yā iyam vākṣā uyam agniḥ sa hotā sā muktiḥ sā atimuktiḥ  yājñavalkya iti ha uvāca yat idam sarvam ahar rātrābhyām āptam
translated: That which is this voice, this is the fire, this is the Hotri. That is the liberation, that is the escape.🔽Yajnavalkya, he said, this whole world is encompassed by day and night,

original: sarvamahorātrābhyāmabhipannaṃ kena yajamāno'horātrayorāptimatimucyata
analyzed: sarvam ahar rātrābhyām abhipannam kena yajamānaḥ ūhorātrayoḥ āptim atimucyata
translated: this whole world is overcome by day and night. By what does the sacrificer escape from the reach of day and night?

original: ityadhvaryuṇartvijā cakṣuṣādityena cakṣurvai yajñasyādhvaryustadyadidaṃ cakṣuḥ
analyzed: iti adhvaryuṇā ṛtvijā cakṣuṣā ādityena cakṣuḥ vai yajñasya adhvaryuḥ tat yat idam cakṣuḥ
translated: By the Adhvaryu priest, by the eye, by the sun. For the eye is the Adhvaryu of the sacrifice. That which is this eye,

original: so'sāvādityaḥ so'dhvaryuḥ sā muktiḥ sātimuktiḥ / / /🔽yājñavalkyeti hovāca yadidaṃ sarvam pūrvapakṣāparapakṣābhyāmāptaṃ sarvam
analyzed: sā usau ādityaḥ sā udhvaryuḥ sā muktiḥ sā atimuktiḥ  yājñavalkya iti ha uvāca yat idam sarvam pūrvapakṣa aparapakṣābhyām āptam sarvam
translated: this is the sun, this is the Adhvaryu. That is the liberation, that is the escape.🔽Yajnavalkya, he said, this whole world is encompassed by the fortnights, this whole world is overcome by the fortnights. By what

original: pūrvapakṣāparapakṣābhyāmabhipannaṃ kena yajamānaḥ
analyzed: pūrvapakṣa aparapakṣābhyām abhipannam kena yajamānaḥ
translated: does the sacrificer escape from the reach of the fortnights?

original: pūrvapakṣāparapakṣayorāptimatimucyata iti brahmaṇartvijā manasā candreṇa mano
analyzed: pūrvapakṣa aparapakṣayoḥ āpti matim ucyate iti brahmaṇā ṛtvijā manasā candreṇa mano
translated: By the Brahman priest, by the mind, by the moon. For the mind is the Brahman priest of the sacrifice.

original: vai yajñasya brahmā tadyadidam manaḥ so'sau candraḥ sa brahmā sā muktiḥ
analyzed: vai yajñasya brahmā tat yat idam manaḥ saḥ asau candraḥ sa brahmā sā muktiḥ
translated: The Brahman of the sacrifice is this mind. That is the moon. That is the Brahman. That is liberation.

original: sātimuktiḥ / / /
analyzed: sā atimuktiḥ
translated: That is the highest liberation.

original: yājñavalkyeti hovāca yadidamantarikṣamanārambaṇamivātha kenākrameṇa
analyzed: yājñavalkya iti ha uvāca yat idam antarikṣam anārambaṇam iva atha kena akrameṇa
translated: Yajnavalkya, he said, this space is as if without support. Then by what means

original: yajamānaḥ svargaṃ lokamākramata ityudgātrartvijā vāyunā prāṇena prāṇo vai
analyzed: yajamānaḥ svargam lokam ākramate iti udgātrā ṛtvijā vāyunā prāṇena prāṇaḥ vai
translated: does the sacrificer ascend to heaven? By the Udgata priest, by Vayu, by Prana. Prana

original: yajñasyodgātā tadyo'yam prāṇa sa vāyuḥ sa udgātā sā muktiḥ sātimuktirityatimokṣā
analyzed: yajñasya udgātā tat yaḥ ayam prāṇa sa vāyuḥ saḥ udgātā sā muktiḥ sā atimuktiḥ iti atimokṣā
translated: is indeed the Udgata of the sacrifice. That which is this Prana, that is Vayu. That is the Udgata. That is liberation. That is the highest liberation. Thus is the highest liberation.

original: atha sampadaḥ / / /
analyzed: atha sampadaḥ
translated: Now, the attainments.

original: yājñavalkyeti hovāca katibhirayamadyargbhirhotāsminyajñe kariṣyatīti tisṛbhiriti
analyzed: yājñavalkya iti ha uvāca katibhiḥ ayam adya ṛgbhiḥ hotā asmin yajñe kariṣyati iti tisṛbhiḥ iti
translated: Yajnavalkya, he said, with how many Rg verses will the Hotri priest perform in this sacrifice today? With three, he said.

original: katamāstāstisra iti puro'nuvākyā ca yājyā ca śasyaiva tṛtīyā kiṃ tābhirjayatīti
analyzed: katamāḥ tāḥ tisraḥ iti puronuvākyā ca yājyā ca śasyā eva tṛtīyā kim tābhiḥ jayati iti
translated: Which are those three? The Puronuvakya, the Yajya, and the Sastra as the third. What does one conquer with them?

original: pṛthivilokameva puro'nuvākyayā jayatyantarikṣalokaṃ yājyayā dyaurlokaṃ śasyayā / / /
analyzed: pṛthivi lokam eva puronuvākyayā jayati antarikṣa lokam yājyayā dyauḥ lokam śasyayā
translated: With the Puronuvakya, one conquers the world of the earth. With the Yajya, one conquers the world of the atmosphere. With the Sastra, one conquers the world of heaven.

original: yājñavalkyeti hovāca katyayamadyādhvaryurasminyajña āhutīrhoṣyatīti tisra iti
analyzed: yājñavalkya iti ha uvāca kati ayam adya adhvaryuḥ asmin yajñe āhutīḥ hoṣyati iti tisraḥ iti
translated: Yajnavalkya, he said, how many oblations will the Adhvaryu priest offer in this sacrifice today? Three, he said.

original: katamāstāstisra iti yā hutā ujjvalanti yā hutā atinedanti yā hutā adhiśerate kiṃ
analyzed: katamāḥ tāḥ tisraḥ iti yāḥ hutāḥ ujjvalanti yāḥ hutāḥ atinedanti yāḥ hutāḥ adhiśerate kim
translated: Which are those three? Those that are offered and blaze up, those that are offered and roar overmuch, and those that are offered and go out.

original: tābhirjayatīti yā hutā ujjvalanti devalokameva tābhirjayati dīpyata iva hi devaloko yā
analyzed: tābhiḥ jayati iti yāḥ hutāḥ ujjvalanti deva lokam eva tābhiḥ jayati dīpyate iva hi deva lokaḥ yā
translated: What does he conquer by them? By those that are offered and blaze up, he conquers the world of the gods; for the world of the gods, as it were, shines.

original: hutā atinedanti manuṣyalokameva tābhirjayatyatīva hi manuṣyaloko yā hutā
analyzed: hutāḥ atinedanti manuṣya lokam eva tābhiḥ jayati atīva hi manuṣya lokaḥ yā hutā
translated: By those that are offered and roar overmuch, he conquers the world of men; for the world of men, as it were, exceeds (the world of the gods).

original: adhiśerate pitṛlokameva tābhirjayatyadha iva hi pitṛlokaḥ / / /🔽yājñavalkyeti hovāca katibhirayamadya brahmā yajñaṃ dakṣiṇato
analyzed: adhiśerate pitṛ lokam eva tābhiḥ jayati adhas iva hi pitṛ lokaḥ  yājñavalkya iti ha uvāca katibhiḥ ayam adya brahmā yajñam dakṣiṇatas
translated: By those that are offered and go out, he conquers the world of the fathers; for the world of the fathers, as it were, is below (the world of men).🔽Yajnavalkya, he said, with how many deities will the Brahman today protect the sacrifice on the south side? With one, he said.

original: devatābhirgopāyiṣyatītyekayeti katamā saiketi mana evetyanantaṃ vai mano'nantā
analyzed: devatābhiḥ gopāyiṣyati iti ekayā iti katamā sā ekā iti manaḥ eva iti anantam vai manaḥ nantā
translated: Which is that one? The mind, he said. The mind, verily, is infinite.

original: viśve devā anantameva sa tena lokaṃ jayati / / /🔽yājñavalkyeti hovāca katyayamadyodgātāsminyajñe stotriyā stoṣyatīti tisra iti
analyzed: viśve devāḥ anantam eva sa tena lokam jayati  yājñavalkya iti ha uvāca kati ayam adya udgātā asmin yajñe stotriyā stoṣyati iti tisraḥ iti
translated: The All-gods are infinite. The infinite world he conquers by it.🔽Yajnavalkya, he said, how many recitations will the Udgata chant today in this sacrifice? Three, he said.

original: katamāstāstisra iti puro'nuvākyā ca yājyā ca śasyaiva tṛtīyādhidevatamathādhyātmaṃ
analyzed: katamāḥ tāḥ tisraḥ iti puronuvākyā ca yājyā ca śasyā eva tṛtīyā adhidevatam atha adhyātmam
translated: Which are those three? The Puronuvakya, the Yajya, and the Sastra as the third, in the deity. Now in the self.

original: katamāstā yā adhyātmamiti prāṇa eva puronuvākyāpāno yājyā vyānaḥ śasyā kiṃ
analyzed: katamāḥ tāḥ yāḥ adhyātmam iti prāṇaḥ eva puronuvākyā apānaḥ yājyā vyānaḥ śasyā kim
translated: What are those (three) which are internal? The out-breathing is the Puronuvakya, the in-breathing is the Yâgyâ, the through-breathing is the Sastra.

original: tābhirjayatīti yatkiṃ cedam prāṇabhṛditi tato ha hotāśvala upararāma / / /🔽atha hainaṃ jāratkārava ārtabhāgaḥ papraca yājñavalkyeti hovāca kati grahāḥ
analyzed: tābhiḥ jayati iti yat kim ca idam prāṇabhṛt iti tatas ha hotā āśvalaḥ upararāma  atha ha enam jāratkāravaḥ ārtabhāgaḥ papraca yājñavalkya iti ha uvāca kati grahāḥ
translated: What does he conquer by them? Whatever there is that breathes by the breath. Thereupon the Hotri Asvalâyana became silent.

original: katyatigrahā ityaṣṭau grahā aṣṭāvatigrahā ye te'ṣṭau grahā aṣṭāvatigrahāḥ katame🔽ta iti / / /🔽prāṇo vai grahaḥ so'pānenātigraheṇa gṛhīto'pānena hi gandhānjighrati / / /
analyzed: kati atigrahāḥ iti aṣṭau grahāḥ aṣṭau atigrahāḥ ye te aṣṭau grahāḥ aṣṭau atigrahāḥ katame  te iti  prāṇaḥ vai grahaḥ sa upānena atigraheṇa gṛhītā upānena hi gandhān jighrati
translated: Then Jâratkârava Ârtabhaga asked him, 'Yâgñavalkya,' said he, 'how many are the cups (of Soma), and how many the over-cups?'--'Eight are the cups, and eight the over-cups.'--'Those eight cups and eight over-cups, which are they?'🔽'The out-breathing, forsooth, is a cup, and that is taken by the in-breathing as the over-cup, for by the in-breathing one smells scents.'

original: jihvā vai grahaḥ sa rasenātigraheṇa gṛhīto jihvayā hi rasānvijānāti / / /
analyzed: jihvā vai grahaḥ sa rasena atigraheṇa gṛhītaḥ jihvayā hi rasān vijānāti
translated: 'The tongue, forsooth, is a cup, and that is taken by taste as the over-cup, for by the tongue one discerns tastes.'

original: vāgvai grahaḥ sa nāmnātigraheṇa gṛhīto vācā hi nāmānyabhivadati / / /
analyzed: vāc vai grahaḥ sa nāmnā atigraheṇa gṛhītaḥ vācā hi nāmāni abhivadati
translated: 'Speech, forsooth, is a cup, and that is taken by the name as the over-cup, for by speech one utters names.'

original: cakṣurvai grahaḥ sa rūpeṇātigraheṇa gṛhītaścakṣuṣā hi rūpāṇi paśyati / / /
analyzed: cakṣuḥ vai grahaḥ sa rūpeṇa atigraheṇa gṛhītaḥ cakṣuṣā hi rūpāṇi paśyati
translated: 'The eye, forsooth, is a cup, and that is taken by the form as the over-cup, for by the eye one sees forms.'

original: śrotraṃ vai grahaḥ sa śabdenātigraheṇa gṛhītaḥ śrotreṇa hi śabdāñcṛṇoti / / /
analyzed: śrotram vai grahaḥ sa śabdena atigraheṇa gṛhītaḥ śrotreṇa hi śabdān cṛṇoti
translated: 'The ear, forsooth, is a cup, and that is taken by sound as the over-cup, for by the ear one hears sounds.'

original: mano vai grahaḥ sa kāmenātigraheṇa gṛhīto manasā hi kāmānkāmayate / / /
analyzed: manaḥ vai grahaḥ sa kāmena atigraheṇa gṛhītaḥ manasā hi kāmān kāmayate
translated: The mind, verily, is a graha. It is seized by the atigraha of desire, for by the mind one desires desires.

original: hastau vai grahaḥ sa karmaṇātigraheṇa gṛhīto hastābhyāṃ hi karma karoti / / /
analyzed: hastau vai grahaḥ sa karmaṇā atigraheṇa gṛhītaḥ hastābhyām hi karma karoti
translated: The hands, verily, are a graha. They are seized by the atigraha of action, for by the hands one performs action.

original: tvagvai grahaḥ sa sparśenātigraheṇa gṛhītastvacā hi sparśānvedayata ityaṣṭau grahā
analyzed: tvac vai grahaḥ sa sparśena atigraheṇa gṛhītaḥ tvacā hi sparśān vedayate iti aṣṭau grahā
translated: The skin, verily, is a graha. It is seized by the atigraha of touch, for by the skin one feels touches. Thus there are eight grahas

original: aṣṭāvatigrahāḥ / / /🔽yājñavalkyeti hovāca yadidaṃ sarvam mṛtyorannaṃ kā svitsā devatā yasyā
analyzed: aṣṭau atigrahāḥ  yājñavalkya iti ha uvāca yat idam sarvam mṛtyoḥ annam kā svid sā devatā yasyāḥ
translated: and eight atigrahas.

original: mṛtyurannamityagnirvai mṛtyuḥ so'pāmannamapa punarmṛtyuṃ jayati / / /🔽yājñavalkyeti hovāca yatrāyam puruṣo mriyate kimenaṃ na jahātīti nāmetyanantaṃ
analyzed: mṛtyuḥ annam iti agniḥ vai mṛtyuḥ sa upa ām annam apa punarmṛtyum jayati  yājñavalkya iti ha uvāca yatra ayam puruṣaḥ mriyate kim enam na jahāti iti nāma iti anantam
translated: Yajnavalkya, he said, this all is the food of death. What, now, is that deity of which death is the food? Agni, verily, is death. He is the food of the waters. By the waters he conquers death again.

original: vai nāmānantā viśve devā anantameva sa tena lokaṃ jayati eva sa tena lokaṃ jayati / / /
analyzed: vai nāma anantāḥ viśve devāḥ anantam eva sa tena lokam jayati eva sa tena lokam jayati
translated: Yajnavalkya, he said, when this person dies, does the name not leave him? No, indeed, he said. The name is infinite. The infinite All-gods are infinite. By that he conquers an infinite world. By that he conquers an infinite world.

original: yājñavalkyeti hovāca yatrāyam puruṣo mriyata udasmātprāṇāḥ krāmantyāho neti neti
analyzed: yājñavalkya iti ha uvāca yatra ayam puruṣaḥ mriyate ud asmāt prāṇāḥ krāmanti āho na iti na iti
translated: Yajnavalkya, he said, when this person dies, do the vital breaths depart from him, or not? No, indeed, he said.

original: hovāca yājñavalkyo'traiva samavanīyante sa ucvayatyādhmāyatyādhmāto mṛtaḥ śete / / /
analyzed: ha uvāca yājñavalkya utra eva samavanīyante saḥ ucvayati ādhmāyati ādhmātaḥ mṛtaḥ śete
translated: Yājñavalkya said: Here they are collected together. He swells, he blows, blown up, he lies dead. . . .

original: yājñavalkyeti hovāca yatrāsya puruṣasya mṛtasyāgniṃ vāgapyeti vātam
analyzed: yājñavalkya iti ha uvāca yatra asya puruṣasya mṛtasya agnim vāc apyeti vātam
translated: Yājñavalkya, he said, when this man dies, his speech goes to fire,

original: prāṇaścakṣurādityam manaścandraṃ diśaḥ śrotram pṛthivīṃ
analyzed: prāṇaḥ cakṣuḥ ādityam manaḥ candram diśaḥ śrotram pṛthivīm
translated: his breath to wind, his eye to the sun, his mind to the moon, his ear to the quarters, the earth🔽to his body, the sky to his soul, the plants to his hair, the trees to his hair, the waters

original: śarīramākāśamātmauṣadhīrlomāni vanaspatīnkeśā apsu lohitaṃ ca retaśca nidhīyate
analyzed: śarīram ākāśam ātmā oṣadhīḥ lomāni vanaspatīn keśāḥ apsu lohitam ca retaḥ ca nidhīyate
translated: to his blood and semen.

original: kvāyaṃ tadā puruṣo bhavatītyāhara saumya hastam / / /
analyzed: kva ayam tadā puruṣaḥ bhavati iti āhara saumya hastam
translated: Where does this man become then? Bring the spoon, my dear, he said. . . .

original: ārtabhāgeti hovāca āvamevaitadvediṣyāvo na nāvetatsajana iti tau hotkrasya
analyzed: ārtabhāga iti ha uvāca āvām eva etat vediṣyāvaḥ na nau etat sa jane iti tau ha utkrasya
translated: Ārtabhāga said, Let us find out about this, let us not quarrel about it. They went away

original: mantrayāṃ cakratustau ha yadūcatuḥ karma haiva tadūcaturatha ha yatpraśaśaṃsatuḥ
analyzed: cakratuḥ tau ha yat ūcatuḥ karma ha eva tat ūcatuḥ atha ha yat praśaśaṃsatuḥ
translated: and deliberated. What they said was indeed an act, and what they praised

original: karma haiva tatpraśaśaṃsatuḥ puṇyo vai puṇyena karmaṇā bhavati pāpaḥ pāpeneti tato
analyzed: karma ha eva tat praśaśaṃsatuḥ puṇyaḥ vai puṇyena karmaṇā bhavati pāpaḥ pāpena iti
translated: was indeed an act. One becomes good through good deeds, and bad through bad deeds, said Ārtabhāga.

original: ha jāratkārava ārtabhāga upararāma / / /
analyzed: ha jāratkāravaḥ ārtabhāgaḥ upararāma
translated: Then Jāratkārava Ārtabhāga became silent.

original: atha hainam bhujyurlāhyāyaniḥ papraca yājñavalkyeti hovāca madreṣu carakāḥ
analyzed: atha ha enam bhujyuḥ lāhyāyaniḥ papraca yājñavalkya iti ha uvāca madreṣu carakāḥ
translated: Then Bhujyu Lāhāyani asked him. Yājñavalkya, he said, the Carakas in Madra

original: paryavrajāma te etañcalasya kāpyasya gṛhānaima tasyāsīdduhitā gandharvagṛhītā
analyzed: paryavrajāma te etañcalasya kāpyasya gṛhān aima tasya āsīt duhitā gandharva gṛhītā
translated: We went round to the house of Calaka Kapya. He had a daughter seized by a Gandharva.

original: tamapṛcāma ko'sīti so'bravītsudhanvāṅgirasa iti taṃ yadā
analyzed: tam apṛcāma kaḥ asi iti saḥ ubravīt sudhanvā āṅgirasaḥ iti tam yadā
translated: We asked him, 'Who are you?' He said, 'I am Sudhanvan Angiras.' When

original: lokānāmantānapṛcāmāthaitamabrūma kva pārikṣitā abhavankva pārikṣitā🔽abhavanniti tattvā pṛcāmi yājñavalkya kva pārikṣitā abhavanniti / / /
analyzed: lokānām antān apṛcāma atha etam abrūma kva pārikṣitāḥ abhavan kva pārikṣitā  abhavan iti tat tvā pṛcāmi yājñavalkya kva pārikṣitāḥ abhavan iti
translated: we asked him about the ends of the worlds, we said to him, 'Where did the sons of Parikshit go? Where did the sons of Parikshit go?'🔽'I ask you about that, Yajnavalkya. Where did the sons of Parikshit go?'

original: sa hovāca uvāca vai sa tadagacanvai te tatra yatrāśvamedhayājino gacantīti kva
analyzed: sa ha uvāca uvāca vai sa tat agacan vai te tatra yatra aśvamedha yājinaḥ gacanti iti kva
translated: He said, 'He said, They have indeed gone where those who perform the horse sacrifice go.' Where do those who perform the horse sacrifice go?

original: nvaśvamedhayājino gacantīti dvātriṃśataṃ vai devarathāhnūyānyayaṃ lokastaṃ
analyzed: nu aśvamedha yājinaḥ gacanti iti dvātriṃśatam vai deva rathā ahnūyāni ayam lokaḥ tam
translated: Thirty-two times the distance of the world of the gods by chariot is this world.

original: samantaṃ lokaṃ dvistāvatpṛthivī paryeti tām pṛthivīṃ dvistāvatsamudraḥ paryeti🔽tadyāvatī kṣurasya dhārā yāvadvā makṣikāyāḥ patraṃ tāvānantareṇākāśastānindraḥ
analyzed: samantam lokam dvis tāvat pṛthivī paryeti tām pṛthivīm dvis tāvat samudraḥ paryeti  tat yāvatī kṣurasya dhārā yāvat vā makṣikāyāḥ patram tāvān antareṇa ākāśaḥ tān indraḥ
translated: The earth extends around this world twice that distance. The ocean extends around that earth twice that distance.🔽As much as the edge of a razor or the wing of a fly, so much is the space in between. Indra,

original: suparṇo bhūtvā vāyave prāyacattānvāyurātmani dhitvā tatrāgamayadyatra pārikṣitā
analyzed: suparṇaḥ bhūtvā vāyave prāyacat tān vāyuḥ ātmani dhitvā tatra agamayat yatra pārikṣitā
translated: having become a bird, gave them to Vayu. Vayu, having placed them in himself, brought them there where the sons of Parikshit were.

original: abhavannityevamiva vai sa vāyumeva praśaśaṃsa tasmādvāyureva vyaṣṭirvāyuḥ
analyzed: abhavan iti evam iva vai sa vāyum eva praśaśaṃsa tasmāt vāyuḥ eva vyaṣṭiḥ vāyuḥ
translated: He became, as it were; he praised Vayu; therefore Vayu is the Vyashti, Vayu is the Vyashti.

original: samaṣṭirapa punarmṛtyuṃ jayati sarvamāyureti ya evaṃ veda tato ha
analyzed: samaṣṭiḥ apa punarmṛtyum jayati sarvam āyuḥ eti yaḥ evam veda tatas ha
translated: He became, as it were, he praised Vāyu in this way. Therefore, Vāyu is the individual soul, Vāyu is the universal soul. Moreover, he conquers death and attains the full life span, who knows this. Then

original: bhujyurlāhyāyanirupararāma / / /🔽atha hainaṃ kahoḍaḥ kauṣītakeyaḥ papraca yājñavalkyeti hovāca
analyzed: bhujyuḥ lāhyāyaniḥ upararāma  atha ha enam kahoḍaḥ kauṣītakeyaḥ papraca yājñavalkya iti ha uvāca
translated: Bhūjyu Lāhyāyana stopped.

original: yatsākṣādaparokṣādbrahma ya ātmā sarvāntarastam me vyācakṣvetyeṣa ta ātmā
analyzed: yat sākṣāt aparokṣāt brahma yaḥ ātmā sarva antaraḥ tam me vyācakṣva iti eṣa te ātmā
translated: Then Kahoda Kauṣītakeya asked him. He said, Yājñavalkya, tell me about that Brahman which is directly perceived, not inferred, the Self within all. This is the Self

original: sarvāntaraḥ katamo yājñavalkya sarvāntaro yo'ṣanāyāpipāse śokam mohaṃ jarām
analyzed: sarva antaraḥ katamaḥ yājñavalkya sarva antaraḥ yoṣanāyā pipāse śokam moham jarām
translated: within all. Which is the Self within all, Yājñavalkya? He who transcends hunger and thirst, sorrow and delusion, old age and

original: mṛtyumatyetyetaṃ vai tamātmānaṃ viditvā brāhmaṇāḥ putraiṣaṇāyāśca vittaiṣaṇāyāśca
analyzed: mṛtyum atyeti etam vai tam ātmānam viditvā brāhmaṇāḥ putra eṣaṇāyāḥ ca vitta eṣaṇāyāḥ ca
translated: death. Having known this Self, the Brahmins turn away from the desire for offspring, the desire for wealth,

original: lokaiṣaṇāyāśca vyutthāyātha bhikṣācaryaṃ caranti yā hyeva putraiṣaṇā sā vittaiṣaṇā
analyzed: loka eṣaṇāyāḥ ca vyutthāya atha bhikṣā caryam caranti yā hi eva putra eṣaṇā sā vitta eṣaṇā
translated: and the desire for worlds, and then wander forth as mendicants. For the desire for offspring is the same as the desire for wealth,

original: yā vittaiṣaṇā sā lokaiṣaṇobhe hyete eṣaṇe eva bhavatastasmātpaṇḍitaḥ pāṇḍityaṃ
analyzed: yā vitta eṣaṇā sā loka eṣaṇā ubhe hi ete eṣaṇe eva bhavataḥ tasmāt paṇḍitaḥ pāṇḍityam
translated: and the desire for wealth is the same as the desire for worlds. Both of these are indeed desires alone. Therefore, the learned one, having learned

original: nirvidya bālyena tiṣṭhāsedbālyaṃ ca pāṇḍityaṃ ca nirvidyātha muniramaunaṃ ca🔽maunaṃ ca nirvidyātha brāhmaṇaḥ sa brāhmaṇaḥ kena syādyena syāttenedṛśa eva
analyzed: nirvidya bālyena tiṣṭhāset bālyam ca pāṇḍityam ca nirvidya atha muniḥ amaunam ca  maunam ca nirvidya atha brāhmaṇaḥ sa brāhmaṇaḥ kena syāt yena syāt tena īdṛśaḥ eva
translated: Having become disgusted with childhood, he should desire to remain [in the state of a child]. Having become disgusted with childhood and scholarship, then he is a sage. Having become disgusted with silence and non-silence,

original: bhavati ya evaṃ veda tato ha kahoḍaḥ kauṣītakeya upararāma / /🔽atha hainamuṣastaścākrāyaṇaḥ papraca yājñavalkyeti hovāca
analyzed: bhavati yaḥ evam veda tatas ha kahoḍaḥ kauṣītakeyaḥ upararāma  atha ha enam uṣastaḥ cākrāyaṇaḥ papraca yājñavalkya iti ha uvāca
translated: then he is a Brahmin. By what would he be a Brahmin? By that, he becomes just like this. One who knows thus, then Kahoḍa Kaushiṭakeya ceased [his questioning].

original: yatsākṣādaparokṣādbrahma ya ātmā sarvāntarastam me vyācakṣvetyeṣa ta ātmā
analyzed: yat sākṣāt aparokṣāt brahma yaḥ ātmā sarva antaraḥ tam me vyācakṣva iti eṣa te ātmā
translated: Then Uṣasta Cākrāyaṇa asked him. He said, Yājñavalkya, tell me about that Brahman which is directly perceived, not hidden, the Self within all. He said, This is the Self within all.

original: sarvāntaraḥ katamo yājñavalkya sarvāntaro yaḥ prāṇena prāṇiti sa ta ātmā sarvāntaro
analyzed: sarva antaraḥ katamaḥ yājñavalkya sarva antaraḥ yaḥ prāṇena prāṇiti sa te ātmā sarva antaraḥ
translated: Which is the Self within all, O Yājñavalkya? He said, The one who breathes by means of the out-breath, he is the Self within all.

original: yo'pānenāpāniti sa ta ātmā sarvāntaro yo vyānena vyaniti sa ta ātmā sarvāntaro ya
analyzed: yaḥ upānena apāniti sa te ātmā sarva antaraḥ yaḥ vyānena vyaniti sa te ātmā sarva antaraḥ yaḥ
translated: The one who breathes by means of the in-breath, he is the Self within all. The one who breathes by means of the through-breath, he is the Self within all.

original: udānenodaniti sa ta ātmā sarvāntaro yaḥ samānena samaniti sa ta ātmā sarvāntaraḥ sa
analyzed: udānena udaniti sa te ātmā sarva antaraḥ yaḥ samānena samaniti sa te ātmā sarva antaraḥ sa
translated: The one who breathes by means of the up-breath, he is the Self within all. The one who breathes by means of the equalizing breath, he is the Self within all.

original: hovācoṣastaścākrāyaṇo yathā vai brūyādasau gaurasāvaśva
analyzed: ha uvāca uṣastaḥ cākrāyaṇaḥ yathā vai brūyāt asau gauḥ asau aśva
translated: Uṣasta Cākrāyaṇa said, Just as one might say, 'That is a cow, that is a horse,' or 'That is not a cow, that is not a horse,'

original: ityevamevaitadvyapadiṣṭam bhavati yadeva sākṣādaparokṣādbrahma ya ātmā
analyzed: iti evam eva etat vyapadiṣṭam bhavati yat eva sākṣāt aparokṣāt brahma yaḥ ātmā
translated: Thus it is that this is indicated, that which is the Brahman directly and non-indirectly, that which is the Self

original: sarvāntarastam me vyācakṣvetyeṣa ta ātmā sarvāntaraḥ katamo yājñavalkya
analyzed: sarva antaraḥ tam me vyācakṣva iti eṣa te ātmā sarva antaraḥ katamaḥ yājñavalkya
translated: within all, explain that to me. This is that Self within all. Which one, Yajnavalkya?

original: sarvāntaro na dṛṣṭerdraṣṭāram paśyerna śruteḥ śrotāraṃ śṛṇuyā na matermantāram
analyzed: sarva antaraḥ na dṛṣṭeḥ draṣṭāram paśyeḥ na śruteḥ śrotāram śṛṇuyāḥ na mateḥ mantāram
translated: The one within all. Not of sight is the seer, nor of hearing is the hearer, nor of thought is the thinker,

original: manvīthā na vijñātervijñātāraṃ vijñānīyā eṣa ta ātmā sarvāntaro'to'nyadārtaṃ tato
analyzed: manvīthāḥ na vijñāteḥ vijñātāram vijñānīyāḥ eṣa te ātmā sarva antarā uta unyat ārtam
translated: nor of understanding is the knower. This is that Self within all. Other than that is misery.

original: hoṣastaścākrāyaṇa upararāma / / /
analyzed: ha uṣastaḥ cākrāyaṇaḥ upararāma
translated: Therefore, Hotr, and Svapakṣa, and Akrāyaṇa became silent.

original: atha hainaṃ gārgī vācaknavī papraca yājñavalkyeti hovāca yaditaṃ sarvamapsvotaṃ🔽ca protaṃ ca kasminnvāpa otāśca protaśceti vāyau gārgīti kasminnu vāyurotaśca🔽protaścetyākāśa eva gārgīti kasminnvākāśa otaśca protaścetyantarikṣalokeṣu gārgīti
analyzed: atha ha enam gārgī vācaknavī papraca yājñavalkya iti ha uvāca yat itam sarvam apsu otam  ca protam ca kasmin nu āpaḥ otāḥ ca protaḥ ca iti vāyau gārgi iti kasmin nu vāyuḥ otaḥ ca  protaḥ ca iti ākāśe eva gārgi iti kasmin u ākāśaḥ otaḥ ca protaḥ ca iti antarikṣa lokeṣu gārgi iti
translated: Then Gārgi Vācaknavī asked him, Yājñavalkya, she said, if all this is woven in and woven out in the waters,🔽in what, then, are the waters woven in and woven out? In the wind, Gārgi, he said. In what, then, is the wind woven in and woven out? In space, Gārgi. In what, then, is space woven in and woven out? In the worlds of the atmosphere, Gārgi.

original: kasminnvantarikṣalokā otāśca protāśceti dyaurloke gārgīti kasminnu dyaurloka
analyzed: kasmin u antarikṣa lokāḥ otāḥ ca protāḥ ca iti dyauḥ loke gārgi iti kasmin nu dyauḥ loke
translated: In what, then, are the worlds of the atmosphere woven in and woven out? In the world of the sky, Gārgi. In what, then, is the world of the sky woven in and woven out?🔽In the world of the sun, Gārgi. In what, then, is the world of the sun woven in and woven out?

original: otaśca protaścetyādityalokeṣu gārgīti kasminnvādityalokā otāśca protāśceti
analyzed: otaḥ ca protaḥ ca iti āditya lokeṣu gārgi iti kasmin u āditya lokāḥ otāḥ ca protāḥ ca iti
translated: The worlds of the sun, O Gārgi, are woven warp and woof. In what, O Gārgi, are the worlds of the sun woven warp and woof?

original: candralokeṣu gārgīti kasminnu candralokā otāśca protāśceti nakṣatralokeṣu gārgīti
analyzed: candra lokeṣu gārgi iti kasmin nu candra lokāḥ otāḥ ca protāḥ ca iti nakṣatra lokeṣu gārgi iti
translated: The worlds of the moon, O Gārgi. In what, O Gārgi, are the worlds of the moon woven warp and woof? The worlds of the stars, O Gārgi.

original: kasminnu nakṣatralokā otāśca protāśceti devalokeṣu gārgīti kasminnu devalokā
analyzed: kasmin nu nakṣatra lokāḥ otāḥ ca protāḥ ca iti deva lokeṣu gārgi iti kasmin nu deva lokā
translated: In what, O Gārgi, are the worlds of the stars woven warp and woof? The worlds of the gods, O Gārgi. In what, O Gārgi, are the worlds of the gods woven warp and woof?

original: otāśca protāśceti gandharvalokeṣu gārgīti kasminnu gandharvalokā otāśca protāśceti
analyzed: otāḥ ca protāḥ ca iti gandharva lokeṣu gārgi iti kasmin nu gandharva lokāḥ otāḥ ca protāḥ ca iti
translated: The worlds of the Gandharvas, O Gārgi. In what, O Gārgi, are the worlds of the Gandharvas woven warp and woof?

original: prajāpatilokeṣu gārgīti kasminnu prajāpatilokā otāśca protāśceti brahmalokeṣu🔽gārgīti kasminnu brahmalokā otāśca protāśceti sa hovāca gārgi mātiprākṣīrmā te
analyzed: prajāpati lokeṣu gārgi iti kasmin nu prajāpati lokāḥ otāḥ ca protāḥ ca iti brahma lokeṣu  gārgi iti kasmin nu brahma lokāḥ otāḥ ca protāḥ ca iti sa ha uvāca gārgi mā atiprākṣīḥ mā te
translated: The worlds of Prajāpati, O Gārgi. In what, O Gārgi, are the worlds of Prajāpati woven warp and woof? The worlds of Brahman, O Gārgi.🔽In what, O Gārgi, are the worlds of Brahman woven warp and woof? He said, O Gārgi, ask not too much.

original: mūrdhā vyapaptadanatipraśnyā vai devatā atipṛcasi gārgi mātiprākṣīriti tato ha gārgī
analyzed: mūrdhā vyapaptat anatipraśnyāḥ vai devatāḥ atipṛcasi gārgi mā atiprākṣīḥ iti tatas ha gārgī
translated: Let not thy head fall off. Unanswerable, indeed, are the gods, O Gārgi. Ask not too much. Thereupon Gārgi

original: vācaknavyupararāma / / /
analyzed: vācaknavī upararāma
translated: Vācaknavī held her peace.

original: atha hainamuddālaka āruṇiḥ papraca yājñavalkyeti hovāca madreṣvavasāma
analyzed: atha ha enam uddālakaḥ āruṇiḥ papraca yājñavalkya iti ha uvāca madreṣu avasāma
translated: Then Uddālaka Āruṇi asked him, Yājñavalkya, said he, we have dwelt together as students.

original: patañcalasya kāpyasya gṛheṣu yajñamadhīyānāstasyāsīdbhāryā gandharvagṛhītā
analyzed: patañcalasya kāpyasya gṛheṣu yajñam adhīyānāḥ tasya āsīt bhāryā gandharva gṛhītā
translated: Patanjali, while studying the sacrifice in the house of Kapya, had a wife possessed by a Gandharva.

original: tamapṛcāma ko'sīti so'bravītkabandha ātharvaṇa iti / / /
analyzed: tam apṛcāma kaḥ asi iti saḥ bravīt kabandhaḥ ātharvaṇaḥ iti
translated: They asked him, Who are you? He said, I am Kabandha Atharvana.

original: so'bravīt patañcalaṃ kāpyaṃ yājñikāṃśca vettha nu tvaṃ kāpya tatsūtraṃ yasminnayaṃ
analyzed: saḥ bravīt patañcalam kāpyam yājñikān ca vettha nu tvam kāpya tat sūtram yasmin ayam
translated: He said to Patanjali Kapya, Do you know, O Kapya, that thread, by which

original: ca lokaḥ paraśca lokaḥ sarvāṇi ca bhūtāni saṃdṛbdhāni bhavantīti so'bravītpatañcalaḥ
analyzed: ca lokaḥ paraḥ ca lokaḥ sarvāṇi ca bhūtāni saṃdṛbdhāni bhavanti iti saḥ u bravīt patañcalaḥ
translated: this world, the other world, and all beings are held together? Patanjali said,

original: kāpyo nāhaṃ tadbhagavanvedeti / / /
analyzed: kāpyaḥ na aham tat bhagavan veda iti
translated: I do not know that, O revered one.

original: so'bravīt patañcalaṃ kāpyaṃ yājñikāṃśca vettha nu tvaṃ kāpya tamantaryāmiṇaṃ ya
analyzed: saḥ ubravīt patañcalam kāpyam yājñikān ca vettha nu tvam kāpya tam antaryāmiṇam yaḥ
translated: He said to Patanjali Kapya and the sacrificers, Do you know, O Kapya, that inner controller

original: imaṃ ca lokam paraṃ ca lokaṃ sarvāṇi ca bhūtānyantaro yamayatīti
analyzed: imam ca lokam param ca lokam sarvāṇi ca bhūtāni antaraḥ yamayati iti
translated: who controls this world, the other world, and all beings from within?

original: so'bravītpatañcalaḥ kāpyo nāhaṃ tam bhagavanvedeti / / /
analyzed: saḥ ubravīt patañcalaḥ kāpyaḥ na aham tam bhagavan veda iti
translated: Patanjali said, I do not know him, O revered one.

original: so'bravīt patañcalaṃ kāpyaṃ yājñikāṃśca yo vai tatkāpya sūtraṃ vidyāttaṃ
analyzed: saḥ ubravīt patañcalam kāpyam yājñikān ca yaḥ vai tat kāpya sūtram vidyāt tam
translated: He said to Patanjali Kapya and the sacrificers, He who knows that thread, O Kapya,

original: cāntaryāmiṇaṃ sa brahmavitsa lokavitsa devavitsa vedavitsa yajñavitsa bhūtavitsa
analyzed: ca antaryāmiṇam sa brahma vid sa loka vid sa deva vid sa veda vid sa yajña vid sa bhūta vid sa
translated: and that inner controller, he knows Brahman, he knows the worlds, he knows the gods, he knows the Vedas, he knows the sacrifices, he knows the beings,

original: ātmavitsa sarvaviditi tebhyo'bravīttadahaṃ veda taccettvaṃ yājñavalkya
analyzed: ātma vid sa sarva vid iti tebhyaḥ bravīt tat aham veda tat ced tvam yājñavalkya
translated: He who knows the Self knows all. To them he said, I know that, O Yajnavalkya.

original: sūtramavidvāṃstaṃ cāntaryāmiṇam brahmagavīrudajase mūrdhā te vipatiṣyatīti / / /🔽veda vā ahaṃ gautama tatsūtraṃ taṃ cāntaryāmiṇamiti yo vā idaṃ kaśca
analyzed: sūtram a vidvān tam ca antaryāmiṇam brahma gavīḥ udajase mūrdhā te vipatiṣyati iti  veda vai aham gautama tat sūtram tam ca antaryāmiṇam iti yaḥ vai idam kaḥ ca
translated: If you, O Yajnavalkya, speak of the thread and the immanent Brahman without knowing them, your head will fall off.

original: brūyādvedavedeti yathā vettha tathā brūhīti / / /
analyzed: brūyāt veda veda iti yathā vettha tathā brūhi iti
translated: Gautama said, I know that thread and the immanent Brahman. Whoever would say, You know the Veda, as you know, speak thus.

original: vāyurvai gautama tatsūtram vāyunā vai gautama sūtreṇāyaṃ ca lokaḥ paraśca lokaḥ🔽sarvāṇi ca bhūtāni saṃdṛbdhāni bhavanti tasmādvai gautama puruṣam🔽pretamāhurvyasraṃsiṣatāsyāṅgānīti vāyunā hi gautama sūtreṇa saṃdṛbdhāni
analyzed: vāyuḥ vai gautama tat sūtram vāyunā vai gautama sūtreṇa ayam ca lokaḥ paraḥ ca lokaḥ  sarvāṇi ca bhūtāni saṃdṛbdhāni bhavanti tasmāt vai gautama puruṣam  pretam āhuḥ vyasraṃsiṣata asya aṅgāni iti vāyunā hi gautama sūtreṇa saṃdṛbdhāni
translated: Gautama said, Air, O Yajnavalkya, is that thread. By air, O Yajnavalkya, as by a thread, this world and the other world,

original: bhavantītyevamevaitadyājñavalkyāntaryāmiṇam brūhīti / / /
analyzed: bhavanti iti evam eva etat yājñavalkya antaryāmiṇam brūhi iti
translated: and all beings are held together. Therefore, O Yajnavalkya, when a man dies, they say, 'His limbs have fallen apart,' for by air, O Yajnavalkya, as by a thread, they are held together. Even so, O Yajnavalkya, speak of the immanent Brahman.

original: yaḥ pṛthivyāṃ tiṣṭhan pṛthivyā antaro yam pṛthivī na veda yasya pṛthivī śarīraṃ yaḥ
analyzed: yaḥ pṛthivyām tiṣṭhan pṛthivyāḥ antaraḥ yam pṛthivī na veda yasya pṛthivī śarīram yaḥ
translated: He who, standing in the earth, is yet within the earth, whom the earth does not know, whose body the earth is,

original: pṛthivīmantaro yamayati sa ta ātmāntaryāmyamṛtaḥ / / /
analyzed: pṛthivīm antaraḥ yamayati sa te ātmā antaryāmī amṛtaḥ
translated: who controls the earth from within, he is your self, the inner controller, the immortal.
