translated: his world comes to an end. O Gargi, he who departs from this world without knowing that Imperishable One,

original: gārgyasmāllokātpraiti sa kṛpaṇo'tha ya etadakṣaraṃ gārgi viditvāsmāllokātpraiti sa
analyzed: gārgi asmāt lokāt praiti sa kṛpaṇā utha yaḥ etat akṣaram gārgi viditvā asmāt lokāt praiti sa
translated: he is a poor man. But he who departs from this world knowing that Imperishable One, O Gargi,

original: brāhmaṇaḥ / / /
analyzed: brāhmaṇaḥ
translated: he is a Brahmin.

original: tadvā etadakṣaraṃ gārgi adṛṣṭaṃ draṣṭraśrutam mantra/🔽vijñātaṃ vijñātṛ nānyadasti
analyzed: tat vai etat akṣaram gārgi a dṛṣṭam draṣṭṛ a śrutam mantra  vijñātam vijñātṛ na anyat asti
translated: That Imperishable One, O Gargi, is unseen, the seer; unheard, the hearer;

original: draṣṭṛ nānyadasti śrotṛ nānyadasti mantṛ nānyadasti vijñātretadvai tadakṣaraṃ gārgi
analyzed: draṣṭṛ na anyat asti śrotṛ na anyat asti mantṛ na anyat asti vijñātṛ etat vai tat akṣaram gārgi
translated: unthought, the thinker; unknown, the knower. There is nothing else besides it, the seer; there is nothing else besides it, the hearer; there is nothing else besides it, the thinker; there is nothing else besides it, the knower. That, verily, is that Imperishable One, O Gargi,

original: yasminnākāśa otaśca protaśceti / / /
analyzed: yasmin ākāśaḥ otaḥ ca protaḥ ca iti
translated: in whom space is woven warp and woof.

original: sā hovāca brāhmaṇā bhagavantastadeva bahu manyadhvaṃ yadasmānnamaskāreṇa
analyzed: sā ha uvāca brāhmaṇāḥ bhagavantaḥ tat eva bahu manyadhvam yat asmāt namaskāreṇa
translated: She said, 'Venerable Brahmanas, you value that very much by which you release us with a salutation.

original: mucyādhvai na vai jātu yuṣmākamimaṃ kaścidbrahmodyaṃ jeteti tato ha
analyzed: mucyādhvai na vai jātu yuṣmākam imam kaścid brahmodyam jetā iti tatas ha
translated: Indeed, no one will ever defeat you in this Brahmanical debate.' Then

original: vācaknavyupararāma / / /
analyzed: vācaknavī upararāma
translated: Vācaknavī became silent.

original: atha hainaṃ vidagdhaḥ śākalyaḥ papraca kati devā yājñavalkyeti sa haitayaiva nividā
analyzed: atha ha enam vidagdhaḥ śākalyaḥ papraca kati devāḥ yājñavalkya iti sa ha etayā eva nividā
translated: Then Vidagdha Śākalya asked him, 'How many gods are there, Yājñavalkya?' He answered with that very verse:

original: pratipede yāvanto vaiśvadevasya nividyucyante trayaśca trī ca śatā trayaśca trī ca🔽sahasretyomiti hovāca / / /
analyzed: pratipede yāvantaḥ vaiśvadevasya nivid yucyante trayaḥ ca trī ca śatā trayaḥ ca trī ca  sahasra iti om iti ha uvāca
translated: 'As many as are mentioned in the Vaisvadeva hymn - three hundred and three, and three thousand.' 'Yes,' he said.

original: katyeva devā yājñavalkyeti trayastriṃśadityomiti hovāca katyeva devā yājñavalkyeti
analyzed: kati eva devāḥ yājñavalkya iti trayastriṃśat iti om iti ha uvāca kati eva devāḥ yājñavalkya iti
translated: 'How many gods are there, Yājñavalkya?' 'Thirty-three,' he said. 'Yes.' 'How many gods are there, Yājñavalkya?'

original: ṣaḍityomiti hovāca katyeva devā yājñavalkyeti traya ityomiti hovāca katyeva devā🔽yājñavalkyeti dvāvityomiti hovāca katyeva devā yājñavalkyetyadhyardha ityomiti
analyzed: ṣaṭ iti om iti ha uvāca kati eva devāḥ yājñavalkya iti trayaḥ iti om iti ha uvāca kati eva devāḥ  yājñavalkya iti dvau iti om iti ha uvāca kati eva devāḥ yājñavalkya iti adhyardhaḥ iti om iti
translated: 'Six,' he said. 'Yes.' 'How many gods are there, Yājñavalkya?' 'Three,' he said. 'Yes.' 'How many gods are there,

original: hovāca katyeva devā yājñavalkyetyeka ityomiti hovāca katame te trayaśca trī ca śatā
analyzed: ha uvāca kati eva devāḥ yājñavalkya iti ekaḥ iti om iti ha uvāca katame te trayaḥ ca trī ca śatā
translated: Yājñavalkya?' 'Two,' he said. 'Yes.' 'How many gods are there, Yājñavalkya?' 'One and a half,' he said. 'Yes.' 'How many gods are there, Yājñavalkya?' 'One,' he said. 'Which are those three hundred and three,🔽and three thousand?'

original: trayaśca trī ca sahasreti / / /
analyzed: trayaḥ ca trī ca sahasrā iti
translated: Three and three thousand...

original: sa hovāca mahimāna evaiṣāmete trayastriṃśattveva devā iti katame te
analyzed: sa ha uvāca mahimānaḥ eva eṣām ete trayastriṃśat tu eva devāḥ iti katame te
translated: He said: 'These are their glories. The thirty-three are indeed the gods.' 'Which are the thirty-three?'

original: trayastriṃśadityaṣṭau vasava ekādaśa rudrā dvādaśādityāsta ekatriṃśadindraścaiva🔽prajāpatiśca trayastriṃśāviti / / /
analyzed: trayastriṃśat iti aṣṭau vasavaḥ ekādaśa rudrāḥ dvādaśa ādityāḥ te ekatriṃśat indraḥ ca eva  prajāpatiḥ ca trayastriṃśau iti
translated: 'The eight Vasus, the eleven Rudras, the twelve Adityas, that makes thirty-one, and Indra and Prajapati are the thirty-third.'

original: katame vasava iti agniśca pṛthivī ca vāyuścāntarikṣaṃ cādityaśca dyauśca
analyzed: katame vasavaḥ iti agniḥ ca pṛthivī ca vāyuḥ ca antarikṣam ca ādityaḥ ca dyauḥ ca
translated: 'Which are the Vasus?' 'Agni, earth, Vayu, space, Aditya, heaven,

original: nakṣatrāṇi caite vasava eteṣu hīdaṃ sarvaṃ vasu hitamete hīdaṃ sarvaṃ vāsayante
analyzed: nakṣatrāṇi ca ete vasavaḥ eteṣu hi idam sarvam vasu hitam ete hi idam sarvam vāsayante
translated: and the stars, these are the Vasus. For in them all this wealth is placed, for they make all this wealth (vas)

original: tadyadidaṃ sarvaṃ vāsayante tasmādvasava iti / / /
analyzed: tat yat idam sarvam vāsayante tasmāt vasavaḥ iti
translated: to grow. Since they make all this wealth to grow, therefore they are the Vasus.'

original: katame rudrā iti daśeme puruṣe prāṇā ātmaikādaśaste
analyzed: katame rudrāḥ iti daśa ime puruṣe prāṇāḥ ātmā ekādaśaḥ te
translated: 'Which are the Rudras?' 'These ten breaths in man, and the self is the eleventh.

original: yadāsmānmartyācarīrādutkrāmantyatha rodayanti tadyadrodayanti tasmādrudrā iti / / /
analyzed: yadā asmāt martyāḥ carīrāt utkrāmanti atha rodayanti tat yat rodayanti tasmāt rudrāḥ iti
translated: When they depart from this mortal body, then they make one weep. Since they make one weep, therefore they are the Rudras.'

original: katama ādityā iti dvādaśa māsāḥ saṃvatsarasyaita ādityā ete hīdaṃ sarvamādadānā
analyzed: katame ādityāḥ iti dvādaśa māsāḥ saṃvatsarasya ete ādityāḥ ete hi idam sarvam ādadānā
translated: 'Which are the Adityas?' 'The twelve months of the year, these are the Adityas. For they move along, taking all this

original: yanti tadyadidaṃ sarvamādadānā yanti tasmādādityā iti / / /
analyzed: yanti tat yat idam sarvam ādadānāḥ yanti tasmāt ādityāḥ iti
translated: (world) with them. Since they move along, taking all this (world) with them, therefore they are the Adityas.'

original: katama indraḥ katamaḥ prajāpatiriti stanayitnurevendro yajñaḥ prajāpatiriti katama
analyzed: katamaḥ indraḥ katamaḥ prajāpatiḥ iti stanayitnuḥ eva indraḥ yajñaḥ prajāpatiḥ iti katama
translated: Which is Indra? Which is Prajapati? Indra is indeed the thunder, and Prajapati is the sacrifice. Which is the sacrifice? The oblation is the sacrifice. Which is the oblation? The food is the oblation. Which is the food? The rice is the food. Which is the rice? The seed is the rice. Which is the seed? The semen is the seed. Which is the semen? The pleasure is the semen. Which is the pleasure? The truth is the pleasure. Which is the truth? The Brahman is the truth. Which is the Brahman? The Self is the Brahman. Which is the Self? This one is the Self. Which is this one? This one is the Self. Thus, indeed, he who knows this obtains the full life span, full of light, full of truth, full of Brahman.

original: stanayitnurityaśaniriti katamo yajña iti paśava iti / / /
analyzed: stanayitnuḥ iti aśaniḥ iti katamaḥ yajñaḥ iti paśavaḥ iti
translated: Which is Indra, which is Prajapati? The thunder is indeed Indra, the sacrifice is Prajapati. Which is the thunder? The thunderbolt. Which is the sacrifice? The animals.

original: katame ṣaḍiti agniśca pṛthivī ca vāyuścāntarikṣaṃ cādityaśca dyauścaite hyevedaṃ🔽sarvaṃ ṣaḍiti / / /🔽katame te trayo devā itīma eva trayo lokā eṣu hīme sarve devā iti katamau dvau
analyzed: katame ṣaṭ iti agniḥ ca pṛthivī ca vāyuḥ ca antarikṣam ca ādityaḥ ca dyauḥ ca ete hi eva idam  sarvam ṣaṣ iti  katame te trayaḥ devāḥ iti ime eva trayaḥ lokāḥ eṣu hi ime sarve devāḥ iti katamau dvau
translated: Which are the six? Fire, earth, air, space, sun, and heaven - these indeed are all this, six.

original: devāvityannaṃ caiva prāṇaśceti katamo'dhyardha iti yo'yam pavata iti / / /🔽tadāhuḥ yadayameka eva pavate'tha kathamadhyardha iti yadasminnidaṃ
analyzed: devau iti annam ca eva prāṇaḥ ca iti katamaḥ adhyardhaḥ iti yaḥ uyam pavate iti  tat āhuḥ yat ayam ekaḥ eva pavatetha katham adhyardhaḥ iti yat asmin idam
translated: Which are those three gods? These very three worlds, for in these are all the gods. Which are the two gods? Food and breath. Which is the half-and-half? This one who blows.

original: sarvamadhyārdhnottenādhyardha iti katama eko deva iti sa brahma tyadityācakṣate / / /🔽pṛthivyeva yasyāyatanam cakṣurloko manojyotiryo vai tam puruṣaṃ
analyzed: sarvam adhyārdhnot tena adhyardhaḥ iti katamaḥ ekaḥ devaḥ iti sa brahma tyad iti ācakṣate  pṛthivī eva yasya āyatanam cakṣuḥ lokaḥ manaḥ jyotiḥ yaḥ vai tam puruṣam
translated: They say, If this one blows as one, then how is he half-and-half? Because in him all this is half-and-half, therefore he is half-and-half. Which is the one god? That is Brahman, they call it.🔽 The earth itself is his abode, the eye is the world, the mind is the light. He who would know that person, the ultimate goal of every self, he would be a knower, O Yajnavalkya.

original: vidyātsarvasyātmanaḥ parāyaṇaṃ sa vai veditā syādyājñavalkya veda vā ahaṃ tam
analyzed: vidyāt sarvasya ātmanaḥ parāyaṇam sa vai veditā syāt yājñavalkya veda vai aham tam
translated: Yajnavalkya said, I know that person, the ultimate goal of every self, whom you ask.

original: puruṣaṃ sarvasyātmanaḥ parāyaṇaṃ yamāttha ya evāyaṃ śārīraḥ puruṣaḥ sa eṣa
analyzed: puruṣam sarvasya ātmanaḥ parāyaṇam yam āttha yaḥ eva ayam śārīraḥ puruṣaḥ saḥ eṣa
translated: The person whom you said is the final resort of all the self, he is indeed this very embodied person.

original: vadaiva śākalya tasya kā devateti striya iti hovāca / / /
analyzed: vada eva śākalya tasya kā devatā iti striyaḥ iti ha uvāca
translated: Just speak, Śākalya. What is his deity? Women, he said.

original: rūpāṇyeva yasyāyatanam cakṣurloko manojyotiryo vai tam puruṣaṃ🔽vidyātsarvasyātmanaḥ parāyaṇaṃ sa vai veditā syādyājñavalkya veda vā ahaṃ tam
analyzed: rūpāṇi eva yasya āyatanam cakṣuḥ lokaḥ manaḥ jyotiḥ yaḥ vai tam puruṣam  vidyāt sarvasya ātmanaḥ parāyaṇam sa vai veditā syāt yājñavalkya veda vai aham tam
translated: The one whose abode is forms, whose world is the eye, whose light is the mind, if one were to know that person

original: puruṣaṃ sarvasyātmanaḥ parāyaṇaṃ yamāttha ya evāsāvāditye puruṣaḥ sa eṣa
analyzed: puruṣam sarvasya ātmanaḥ parāyaṇam yam āttha yaḥ eva asau āditye puruṣaḥ saḥ eṣa
translated: as the final resort of all the self, he would indeed be a knower. Yājñavalkya, I know that person whom you said is the final resort of all the self. He is indeed this very person in the sun.

original: vadaiva śākalya tasya kā devateti cakṣuriti hovāca / / /
analyzed: vada eva śākalya tasya kā devatā iti cakṣuḥ iti ha uvāca
translated: Just speak, Śākalya. What is his deity? The eye, he said.

original: ākāśa eva yasyāyatanam cakṣurloko mano ya evāyaṃ vāyau puruṣaḥ sa eṣa
analyzed: ākāśaḥ eva yasya āyatanam cakṣuḥ lokaḥ manaḥ yaḥ eva ayam vāyau puruṣaḥ saḥ eṣa
translated: The one whose abode is space, whose world is the eye, whose light is the mind, he who is this very person in the wind, he is indeed this very person in the sun.

original: vadaiva śākalya tasya kā devateti prāṇa iti hovāca / / /
analyzed: vada eva śākalya tasya kā devatā iti prāṇaḥ iti ha uvāca
translated: Just speak, Śākalya. What is his deity? The vital breath, he said.

original: kāma eva yasyāyatanam cakṣurloko mano ya evāsau candre puruṣaḥ sa eṣa
analyzed: kāmaḥ eva yasya āyatanam cakṣuḥ lokaḥ manaḥ yaḥ eva asau candre puruṣaḥ saḥ eṣa
translated: The one whose abode is desire, whose world is the eye, whose light is the mind, he who is this very person in the moon, he is indeed this very person in the sun.

original: vadaiva śākalya tasya kā devateti mana iti hovāca / / /
analyzed: vada eva śākalya tasya kā devatā iti manaḥ iti ha uvāca
translated: Just speak, Śākalya. What is his deity? The mind, he said.

original: teja eva yasyāyatanam cakṣurloko mano ya evāyamagnau puruṣaḥ sa eṣa vadaiva
analyzed: tejaḥ eva yasya āyatanam cakṣuḥ lokaḥ manaḥ yaḥ eva ayam agnau puruṣaḥ saḥ eṣa vada eva
translated: Fire is its abode, the eye is its world, the mind. That person who is in the fire, he is to be spoken of.

original: śākalya tasya kā devateti vāgiti hovāca / / /
analyzed: śākalya tasya kā devatā iti vāc iti ha uvāca
translated: Śākalya, what is his deity? Speech, he said.

original: tama eva yasyāyatanam cakṣurloko mano ya evāyaṃ cāyāmayaḥ puruṣaḥ sa eṣa
analyzed: tamaḥ eva yasya āyatanam cakṣuḥ lokaḥ manaḥ yaḥ eva ayam ca ayāmayaḥ puruṣaḥ saḥ eṣa
translated: Darkness is its abode, the eye is its world, the mind. That person who is in the shadow, he is to be spoken of.

original: vadaiva śākalya tasya kā devateti mṛtyuriti hovāca / / /
analyzed: vada eva śākalya tasya kā devatā iti mṛtyuḥ iti ha uvāca
translated: Śākalya, what is his deity? Death, he said.

original: āpa eva yasyāyatanam cakṣurloko mano ya evāyamapsu puruṣaḥ sa eṣa vadaiva
analyzed: āpaḥ eva yasya āyatanam cakṣuḥ lokaḥ manaḥ yaḥ eva ayam apsu puruṣaḥ saḥ eṣa vada eva
translated: Water is its abode, the eye is its world, the mind. That person who is in the water, he is to be spoken of.

original: śākalya tasya kā devateti varuṇa iti hovāca / / /
analyzed: śākalya tasya kā devatā iti varuṇaḥ iti ha uvāca
translated: Śākalya, what is his deity? Varuṇa, he said.

original: reta eva yasyāyatanam cakṣurloko mano ya evāyam putramayaḥ puruṣaḥ sa eṣa
analyzed: retaḥ eva yasya āyatanam cakṣuḥ lokaḥ manaḥ yaḥ eva ayam putra mayaḥ puruṣaḥ saḥ eṣa
translated: Semen is its abode, the eye is its world, the mind. That person who is born of a son, he is to be spoken of.

original: vadaiva śākalya tasya kā devateti prajāpatiriti hovāca / / /
analyzed: vada eva śākalya tasya kā devatā iti prajāpatiḥ iti ha uvāca
translated: Śākalya, what is his deity? Prajāpati, he said.

original: śākalyeti hovāca yājñavalkyaḥ tvāṃ svidime brāhmaṇā iti / / /
analyzed: śākalya iti ha uvāca yājñavalkyaḥ tvām svid ime brāhmaṇāḥ aṅgārāvakṣayaṇam akrata iti
translated: Śākalya, Yājñavalkya said, Are you not the one these Brahmins are talking about?

original: yājñavalkyeti hovāca śākalyo yadidaṃ kurupañcālānām brāhmaṇānatyavādīḥ kim
analyzed: yājñavalkya iti ha uvāca śākalyaḥ yat idam kuru pañcālānām brāhmaṇān atyavādīḥ kim
translated: Śākalya said to Yājñavalkya, Since you have insulted the Brahmins of Kuru and Pañcāla, what is the highest good?

original: brahma vidvāniti diśo veda sadevāḥ sapratiṣṭhā iti yaddiśo vettha sadevāḥ
analyzed: brahma vidvān iti diśaḥ veda sa devāḥ sa pratiṣṭhāḥ iti yat diśaḥ vettha sa devāḥ
translated: He who knows Brahman, he said, knows the directions. I know the directions as having the gods and the foundations, he said. In that you know the directions as having the gods and the foundations,

original: sapratitiṣṭhāḥ / / /
analyzed: sa pratitiṣṭhāḥ
translated: you know the directions as having the gods and the foundations.

original: kiṃdevato'syām prācyāṃ diśyasīti ādityadevata iti sa ādityaḥ kasminpratiṣṭhita iti🔽cakṣuṣīti kasminnu cakṣuḥ pratiṣṭhitam bhavatīti rūpeṣviti cakṣuṣā hi rūpāṇi
analyzed: kiṃdevatā usyām prācyām diśi asi iti āditya devataḥ iti saḥ ādityaḥ kasmin pratiṣṭhitaḥ iti  cakṣuṣi iti kasmin nu cakṣuḥ pratiṣṭhitam bhavati iti rūpeṣu iti cakṣuṣā hi rūpāṇi
translated: What god is in this eastern direction? he said. The sun god, he said. On what is the sun established?

original: paśyati kasminnu rūpāṇi pratiṣṭhitāni bhavantīti hṛdaya iti hṛdayena hi rūpāṇi jānāti
analyzed: paśyati kasmin nu rūpāṇi pratiṣṭhitāni bhavanti iti hṛdaye iti hṛdayena hi rūpāṇi jānāti
translated: On the eyes, he said. But on what is the eye established? On forms, he said, for by the eye one sees forms. But on what are forms established? On the heart, he said, for by the heart one knows forms.

original: hṛdaye hyeva rūpāṇi pratiṣṭhitāni bhavantītyevamevaitadyājñavalkya / / /
analyzed: hṛdaye hi eva rūpāṇi pratiṣṭhitāni bhavanti iti evam eva etat yājñavalkya
translated: Forms are indeed established on the heart, he said. Even so, Yajnavalkya.

original: kiṃdevato'syāṃ dakṣiṇāyāṃ diśyasīti yamadevata iti sa yamaḥ kasminpratiṣṭhita iti🔽dakṣiṇāyāmiti kasminnu dakṣiṇā pratiṣṭhitā bhavatīti śraddhāyāmiti yadā hyeva
analyzed: kiṃdevatā usyām dakṣiṇāyām diśi asi iti yama devataḥ iti sa yamaḥ kasmin pratiṣṭhitaḥ iti  dakṣiṇāyām iti kasmin nu dakṣiṇā pratiṣṭhitā bhavati iti śraddhāyām iti yadā hi eva
translated: What god is in this southern direction? he said. The god Yama, he said. On what is Yama established?🔽On the south, he said. But on what is the south established? On faith, he said, for when one has faith,

original: śraddhatte'tha dakṣiṇāṃ dadāti śraddhāyāṃ hyeva dakṣiṇā pratiṣṭhitā bhavatīti
analyzed: śraddhatte itha dakṣiṇām dadāti śraddhāyām hi eva dakṣiṇā pratiṣṭhitā bhavati iti
translated: then one gives a gift. The south is indeed established on faith, he said.

original: kasminnu śraddhā pratiṣṭhitā bhavatīti hṛdaya iti hṛdayena hi śraddhatte hṛdaye
analyzed: kasmin nu śraddhā pratiṣṭhitā bhavati iti hṛdaye iti hṛdayena hi śraddhatte hṛdaye
translated: 'In what is faith established?' 'In the heart,' (he said), 'for by the heart one has faith.'

original: hyeva śraddhā pratiṣṭhitā bhavatītyevamevaitadyājñavalkya / / /🔽kiṃdevato'syām pratīcyāṃ diśyasīti varuṇadevata iti sa varuṇaḥ kasminpratiṣṭhita
analyzed: hi eva śraddhā pratiṣṭhitā bhavati iti evam eva etat yājñavalkya  kiṃdevatā usyām pratīcyām diśi asi iti varuṇa devataḥ iti sa varuṇaḥ kasmin pratiṣṭhita
translated: 'In the heart, indeed, faith is established,' said Yajnavalkya.🔽'What god is in this western quarter?' 'Varuna,' he said. 'On what is Varuna established?'

original: ityapsviti kasminnvāpaḥ pratiṣṭhitā bhavantīti retasīti kasminnu retaḥ pratiṣṭhitam🔽bhavatīti hṛdaya iti tasmādapi pratirūpaṃ jātamāhurhṛdayādiva sṛpto hṛdayādiva

analyzed: samrāj paramam brahma na enam cakṣuḥ jahāti sarvāṇi enam bhūtāni abhikṣaranti
translated: The emperor is the highest Brahman. The eye does not leave him. All beings gather around him.

original: devo bhūtvā devānapyeti ya evaṃ vidvānetadupāste hastyṛ / / /
analyzed: devaḥ bhūtvā devān apyeti yaḥ evam vidvān etat upāste
translated: Having become a god, he goes even to the gods, he who, knowing this, worships it.

original: abravīnme gardabhīvipīto bhāradvājaḥ śrotraṃ vai brahmeti yathā
analyzed: abravīt me gardabhīvipītaḥ bhāradvājaḥ śrotram vai brahma iti yathā
translated: Garbhi Vipita Bharadvaja said to me: The ear is indeed Brahman. Just as

original: mātṛmānpitṛmānācāryavānbrūyāttathā tadbhāradvājo'bravīcrotraṃ vai
analyzed: mātṛmān pitṛmān ācāryavān brūyāt tathā tat bhāradvājaḥ bravīt crotram vai
translated: one would say to one who respects his mother, father, and teacher, so did Bharadvaja say: The ear is indeed

original: brahmetyaśṛṇvato hi kiṃ syādityabravīttu te tasyāyatanam pratiṣṭhāṃ na
analyzed: brahma iti a śṛṇvataḥ hi kim syāt iti abravīt tu te tasya āyatanam pratiṣṭhām na
translated: Brahman. For what would be of one who does not hear? He said, But he did not tell me its abode and foundation.

original: me'bravīdityekapādvā etatsamrāḍiti / / /
analyzed: mā bravīt iti eka pād vai etat samrāj iti
translated: That is indeed the one-footed emperor.

original: sa vai no brūhi yājñavalkya śrotramevāyatanamākāśaḥ pratiṣṭhānanta ityenadupāsīta
analyzed: sa vai naḥ brūhi yājñavalkya śrotram eva āyatanam ākāśaḥ pratiṣṭhā anantaḥ iti enat upāsīta
translated: Tell us, Yajnavalkya. The ear is indeed the abode, space is the foundation. One should worship it as infinite.

original: kānantatā yājñavalkya diśa eva samrāḍiti hovāca tasmādvai samrāḍyāṃ kāṃ ca diśaṃ
analyzed: kā ananta tā yājñavalkya diśaḥ eva samrāj iti ha uvāca tasmāt vai samrāj yām kām ca diśam
translated: What is the infinity, Yajnavalkya? The directions themselves are the emperor, he said. Therefore, the emperor goes to whatever direction

original: gacati naivāsyā antaṃ gacatyanantā hi diśaḥ śrotraṃ hi diśaḥ śrotraṃ vai samrāṭ
analyzed: gacati na eva asyāḥ antam gacati anantāḥ hi diśaḥ śrotram hi diśaḥ śrotram vai samrāj
translated: one goes, one does not reach its end, for the directions are infinite. The ear is indeed the directions. The ear is indeed the emperor,

original: paramam brahma nainaṃ śrotraṃ jahāti sarvāṇyenam bhūtānyabhikṣaranti / / /
analyzed: paramam brahma na enam śrotram jahāti sarvāṇi enam bhūtāni abhikṣaranti
translated: the highest Brahman. The ear does not leave him. All beings gather around him.

original: devo bhūtvā devānapyeti ya evaṃ vidvānetadupāste hastyṛ / / /
analyzed: devaḥ bhūtvā devān apyeti yaḥ evam vidvān etat upāste
translated: Having become a god, he goes even to the gods, he who, knowing this, worships it thus.

original: abravīnme satyakāmo jāvālo mano vai brahmeti yathā🔽mātṛmānpitṛmānācāryavānbrūyāttathā tatsatyakāmo'bravīnmano vai
analyzed: abravīt me satyakāmaḥ jāvālaḥ manaḥ vai brahma iti yathā  mātṛmān pitṛmān ācāryavān brūyāt tathā tat satyakāmaḥ bravīt manaḥ vai
translated: Satyakāma Jāvāla told me, 'The mind, verily, is Brahman.'

analyzed: brahma iti amanasaḥ hi kim syāt iti abravīt tu te tasya āyatanam pratiṣṭhām na
translated: As one would say to one who respects his mother and father and teacher, so did Satyakāma say, 'The mind, verily, is Brahman.' 'For what would there be of one who has no mind?' he said. 'But he did not tell me its abode and support,' (said Śvetaketu).

original: me'bravīdityekapādvā etatsamrāḍiti / / /🔽sa vai no brūhi yājñavalkya mana evāyatanamākāśaḥ pratiṣṭhānanda ityenadupāsīta
analyzed: mā bravīt iti eka pād vai etat samrāj iti  sa vai naḥ brūhi yājñavalkya manaḥ eva āyatanam ākāśaḥ pratiṣṭhā ānandaḥ iti enat upāsīta
translated: 'Verily, that is the one-footed sovereignty.'🔽'Verily, tell us that, Yājñavalkya. The mind, verily, is the abode, space is the support. One should worship bliss.'

original: kānandatā yājñavalkya mana eva samrāḍiti hovāca manasā vai samrāṭ
analyzed: kā ānanda tā yājñavalkya manaḥ eva samrāj iti ha uvāca manasā vai samrāj
translated: 'What is the blissfulness, Yājñavalkya?' 'The mind, verily, is the emperor,' he said. 'Verily, O emperor,

original: striyamabhiharyati tasyām pratirūpaḥ putro jāyate sa ānando mano vai samrāṭ
analyzed: striyam abhiharyati tasyām pratirūpaḥ putraḥ jāyate saḥ ānandaḥ manaḥ vai samrāj
translated: one approaches a woman with the mind. A son is born in her who is like him. That is bliss. The mind, verily, O emperor,

original: paramam brahma nainam mano jahāti sarvāṇyenam bhūtānyabhikṣaranti / / /
analyzed: paramam brahma na enam manaḥ jahāti sarvāṇi enam bhūtāni abhikṣaranti
translated: is the supreme Brahman. The mind does not leave him. All beings resort to him.'

original: devo bhūtvā devānapyeti ya evaṃ vidvānetadupāste hastyṛ / / /
analyzed: devaḥ bhūtvā devān apyeti yaḥ evam vidvān etat upāste
translated: Having become a god, he goes even to the gods, he who, knowing this, worships it thus.

analyzed: abravīt me vidagdhaḥ śākalyaḥ hṛdayam vai brahma iti yathā
translated: Vidagdha Śākalya told me, 'The heart, verily, is Brahman.'
